Find out if a supply is taxable, zero-rated or exempt

Which best describes the business activity?

STEP 1: Use this mapping to find out if a supply is taxable, zero-rated or exempt. Whether to charge the GST/HST may depend on who the supply is made to and who makes the supply.

STEP 2: If the supply is taxable, find out the place of supply for GST/HST to know whether the GST/HST rate is 5%, 13% or 15%

Your results are not saved. This mapping covers the most common situations. It does not take into account all exceptions/situations and is only provided as a guideline. It does not replace the law.

Generally, every sale, lease or other supply made in Canada is GST/HST taxable at the rate of 5%, 13%, or 15%, based on subsections 165(1) and 165(2) of the Excise Tax Act, unless it is specifically listed as being:

  • zero-rated (taxable at 0%) under Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
  • GST/HST exempt under Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

Is the supply taxable, zero-rated or exempt

Find out if the supply taxable, zero-rated or exempt 

Is the supply taxable, zero-rated or exempt

Find out if the supply taxable, zero-rated or exempt

  • Finished - Most businesses
  • Finished - Financial services
  • Finished - Importing and exporting
  • Finished - Non-profit organization
  • Finished - Charity
  • Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  • In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  • Finished once webpage links are added - Indigenous customer or supplier
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses

What is being supplied?

Generally, every sale, lease or other supply made in Canada is GST/HST taxable at the rate of 5%, 13%, or 15%, based on subsections 165(1) and 165(2) of the Excise Tax Act, unless it is specifically listed as being:

  • zero-rated (taxable at 0%) under Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
  • GST/HST exempt under Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  • Real property
  • Food or drinks
  • Personal services
  • Other retail goods
  • Healthcare services
  • Educational services
  • Transportation services
  • Telecommunication services
  • Agriculture, fishing or animals
  • Medical devices or prescription drugs
  • Admission to sports or entertainment event
  • Home care service rendered to an individual in their home
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property

Which best describes the supply?

Under subsection 221(2) of the Excise Tax Act (ETA), a supplier of a taxable sale of real property is not required to collect tax if one of the following situations apply:

  • the supplier is a non-resident
  • non-residential real property is being sold to a GST/HST registrant
  • residential real property is being sold to a GST/HST registrant that is not an individual

In these situations, subsection 228(4) of the ETA requires the recipient to remit the tax payable amount directly to the Receiver General.

  • Finished - Farmland
  • Finished - Sale of residential property
  • Finished - Conversion to residential use
  • Finished - Lease of residential property
  • Finished - Appropriation for personal use
  • Finished - Lease of commercial real property
  • Finished - Services in relation to real property
  • Finished - Sale of vacant land (other than farmland)
  • Finished - Lease of vacant land (other than farmland)
  • Finished - Merger or amalgamation (transfer of real property)
  • Finished - Sale of commercial real property (other than farmland)
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland

How is the farmland being supplied?

  • Sale
  • Deemed sale
  • Lease, license or similar arrangement
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Sale

Is the farmland being sold to an individual?

In general, if a farmer sells or transfers ownership of farmland to an individual related to the farmer (or a former spouse or former common-law partner of the farmer) who, in turn, uses the land for the individual's own personal use and enjoyment, the sale or transfer is GST/HST exempt. An exemption may also apply where a farmer changes the use of farmland and begins to use the land for their own personal use and enjoyment.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Sale
  5. Is the farmland being sold to an individual? – Yes

Is the seller also an individual?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Sale
  5. Is the farmland being sold to an individual? – Yes
  6. Is the seller also an individual? – Yes

Is the buyer of the farmland related to the seller (or a former spouse or former common-law partner)?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Sale
  5. Is the farmland being sold to an individual? – Yes
  6. Is the seller also an individual? – Yes
  7. Is the buyer of the farmland related to the seller (or a former spouse or former common-law partner)? – Yes

Was the farmland used by the seller in a commercial activity that is the business of farming?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Sale
  5. Is the farmland being sold to an individual? – Yes
  6. Is the seller also an individual? – Yes
  7. Is the buyer of the farmland related to the seller (or a former spouse or former common-law partner)? – Yes
  8. Was the farmland used by the seller in a commercial activity that is the business of farming? – Yes

Was the farmland used by the seller in a commercial activity other than the business of farming?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Sale
  5. Is the farmland being sold to an individual? – Yes
  6. Is the seller also an individual? – Yes
  7. Is the buyer of the farmland related to the seller (or a former spouse or former common-law partner)? – Yes
  8. Was the farmland used by the seller in a commercial activity that is the business of farming? – Yes
  9. Was the farmland used by the seller in a commercial activity other than the business of farming? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:

Section 10 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.5 - Land and associated real property

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:

If a person sells farmland as part of the supply of an ongoing farming business, the supplier and recipient may jointly elect ,using Form GST44, to have no GST/HST payable on the taxable sale. To qualify for the election, the supplier must sell a business or part of the business, not just the individual assets, and the recipient must acquire ownership, possession or use of all or substantially all (90% or more) of the property required to carry on the business.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Sale
  5. Is the farmland being sold to an individual? – Yes
  6. Is the seller also an individual? – Yes
  7. Is the buyer of the farmland related to the seller (or a former spouse or former common-law partner)? – Yes
  8. Was the farmland used by the seller in a commercial activity that is the business of farming? – Yes
  9. Was the farmland used by the seller in a commercial activity other than the business of farming? – No

Is the buyer acquiring the farmland for their own personal use or enjoyment or for the use or enjoyment of a person they are related to?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Sale
  5. Is the farmland being sold to an individual? – Yes
  6. Is the seller also an individual? – Yes
  7. Is the buyer of the farmland related to the seller (or a former spouse or former common-law partner)? – Yes
  8. Was the farmland used by the seller in a commercial activity that is the business of farming? – Yes
  9. Was the farmland used by the seller in a commercial activity other than the business of farming? – No
  10. Is the buyer acquiring the farmland for their own personal use or enjoyment or for the use or enjoyment of a person they are related to? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:

Paragraph 10(a) of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.5 - Land and Associated Real Property

  10. Is the buyer acquiring the farmland for their own personal use or enjoyment or for the use or enjoyment of a person they are related to? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

Section 10 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.5 - Land and associated real property

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:

If a person sells farmland as part of the supply of an ongoing farming business, the supplier and recipient may jointly elect ,using Form GST44, to have no GST/HST payable on the taxable sale. To qualify for the election, the supplier must sell a business or part of the business, not just the individual assets, and the recipient must acquire ownership, possession or use of all or substantially all (90% or more) of the property required to carry on the business.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Sale
  5. Is the farmland being sold to an individual? – Yes
  6. Is the seller also an individual? – No

Does the supply meet the exempting conditions found in section 12 of Part 1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act?

Exempting conditions found in section 12

The sale of farmland is exempt under section 12 of Part 1 of Schedule V to the ETA if a corporation, partnership or trust sells the farmland to a particular individual, an individual related to the particular individual, a former spouse or former common-law partner of the particular individual and if the conditions of the following 2 points are met:

  1. Immediately before the time ownership of the property is transferred, the following conditions have been met:
    • all or substantially all of the property of the person is used in a commercial activity that is the business of farming
    • the particular individual is a member of the partnership, a beneficiary of the trust or a shareholder of, or related to, the corporation
    • the particular individual, the spouse or common-law partner of the particular individual or a child (within the meaning of subsection 70(10) of the Income Tax Act) of the particular individual is actively engaged in the business of the person
  2. Immediately after the ownership of the property is transferred, the farmland is for the buyer's personal use and enjoyment, or for that of a related individual.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Sale
  5. Is the farmland being sold to an individual? – Yes
  6. Is the seller also an individual? – No
  7. Does the supply meet the exempting conditions found in section 12 of Part 1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:

Section 12 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:

Sections 10 and 12 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.5 - Land and associated real property

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:

If a person sells farmland as part of the supply of an ongoing farming business, the supplier and recipient may jointly elect ,using Form GST44, to have no GST/HST payable on the taxable sale. To qualify for the election, the supplier must sell a business or part of the business, not just the individual assets, and the recipient must acquire ownership, possession or use of all or substantially all (90% or more) of the property required to carry on the business.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Sale
  5. Is the farmland being sold to an individual? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:

Sections 10 and 12 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act only provide their farmland GST/HST exemptions for sales to individuals

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.5 - Land and associated real property

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:

If a person sells farmland as part of the supply of an ongoing farming business, the supplier and recipient may jointly elect ,using Form GST44, to have no GST/HST payable on the taxable sale. To qualify for the election, the supplier must sell a business or part of the business, not just the individual assets, and the recipient must acquire ownership, possession or use of all or substantially all (90% or more) of the property required to carry on the business.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Deemed sale

Is the supply a deemed sale of farmland by an individual under either subsection 190(2) or subsection 207(1) of the Excise Tax Act?

Deemed sale under subsection 190(2) of the ETA

There is a deemed sale of property under subsection 190(2) if, at any time, an individual appropriates real property for their personal use and enjoyment (or for that of a related individual, former spouse, or former common-law partner), and if immediately before the appropriation, the property was held for supply or was used or held for use as capital property in the individual's business or other commercial activity and was not a residential complex.

Deemed sale under subsection 207(1) of the ETA

There is a deemed sale of property under subsection 207(1) where an individual who is a registrant ceases to use real property in commercial activities and begins to use the property exclusively for other purposes or primarily for the individual's personal use and enjoyment (or that of a related individual, a former spouse or former common-law partner).

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Deemed sale
  5. Is the supply a deemed sale of farmland by an individual under either subsection 190(2) or subsection 207(1) of the Excise Tax Act? – Yes

Was the farmland used at any time by the individual in a commercial activity that is the business of farming?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Deemed sale
  5. Is the supply a deemed sale of farmland by an individual under either subsection 190(2) or subsection 207(1) of the Excise Tax Act? – Yes
  6. Was the farmland used at any time by the individual in a commercial activity that is the business of farming? – Yes

Was the farmland used, immediately before the ownership is transferred under the supply, by the individual in a commercial activity other than the business of farming?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Deemed sale
  5. Is the supply a deemed sale of farmland by an individual under either subsection 190(2) or subsection 207(1) of the Excise Tax Act? – Yes
  6. Was the farmland used at any time by the individual in a commercial activity that is the business of farming? – Yes
  7. Was the farmland used, immediately before the ownership is transferred under the supply, by the individual in a commercial activity other than the business of farming? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:

Section 11 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  7. Was the farmland used, immediately before the ownership is transferred under the supply, by the individual in a commercial activity other than the business of farming? – No

Is the farmland, immediately after the ownership is transferred under the supply, for the individual's own personal use or enjoyment or for the use or enjoyment of a person they are related to?

  • No

  8. Is the farmland, immediately after the ownership is transferred under the supply, for the individual's own personal use or enjoyment or for the use or enjoyment of a person they are related to? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:

Section 11 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

GST/HST Memorandum 19.5 - Land and associated real property

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Deemed sale
  5. Is the supply a deemed sale of farmland by an individual under either subsection 190(2) or subsection 207(1) of the Excise Tax Act? – No

RESULT:

Unless an exemption applies under another section, the supply is taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:

Section 11 of Part I of Schedule V to the ETA

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.5 - Land and associated real property

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland
  4. How is the farmland being supplied? – Lease, license or similar arrangement

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:

Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act does not exempt the lease of farmland or other commercial real property except in certain situations involving a supplier that is a public service body

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.4.1, Commercial Real Property - Sales and Rentals

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of residential property

Which best describes the residential property being sold?

  • Finished - Newly built home
  • Finished - Used owner-occupied home
  • Finished - Substantially renovated home
  • Finished - Mixed-used property (home and business)
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of residential property
  4. Which best describes the residential property being sold? – Finished - Newly built home

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%
ACT:
Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act does not exempt the sale of a home by a builder 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.1 - Residential real property - Sales

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of residential property
  4. Which best describes the residential property being sold? – Finished - Used owner-occupied home

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt when sold by someone other than the builder. If substantial renovations have been completed, see the topic "Substantially renovated home" instead.
ACT:
Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act  
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.1 - Residential real property - Sales

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of residential property
  4. Which best describes the residential property being sold? – Finished - Substantially renovated home

DEFINITION:
Substantial renovation - is generally when all of the interior of the existing building has been virtually removed or replaced (in other words, gutted) and, upon completion, the renovated or altered building is, or forms part of, a residential complex.
RESULT:
Generally taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%
ACT:

  • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA) excludes the sale of a home by a builder from its GST/HST exemption
  • Subsection 123(1) of the ETA defines "builder"
  • Subsection 190(1) of the ETA deems a person that has substantially renovated a house to be a builder (in the most common circumstances)
REFERENCE:
  • GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.1 - Residential real property - Sales
  • GST/HST Memorandum 19.2 - Residential real property

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of residential property
  4. Which best describes the residential property being sold? – Finished - Mixed-used property (home and business)

RESULT:
The sale of the residential portion is deemed to be a separate supply than the remaining portion of the real property (for example, commercial real property). If the residential portion would have been exempt when sold on its own, it will be exempt when sold together with taxable real property.
ACT:

  • Subsection 136(2) of the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the ETA
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.1 - Residential real property - Sales

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Conversion to residential use

Is the person converting the property an individual?

If a person converts non-residential real property into a residential complex without newly constructing or substantially renovating the property, the conversion is deemed to be a substantial renovation. In such a situation, the person may be treated as a builder who substantially renovated the complex.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Conversion to residential use
  4. Is the person converting the property an individual? – Yes

Did the individual acquire the property to hold or use exclusively as their place of residence, or the place of residence of another individual who is related to, a former spouse of, or a former common-law partner of the individual?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Conversion to residential use
  4. Is the person converting the property an individual? – Yes
  5. Did the individual acquire the property to hold or use exclusively as their place of residence, or the place of residence of another individual who is related to, a former spouse of, or a former common-law partner of the individual? – Yes

RESULT:

Not a taxable supply as per paragraph 190(1)(f) of the Excise Tax Act as the person is not deemed to be a builder of the complex 

ACT:

  • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act  (ETA)
  • Paragraph 190(1)(f) of the ETA makes an exception in this case so that the person is not deemed to be a builder of the complex

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.3 - Residential real property - Deemed supplies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Conversion to residential use
  4. Is the person converting the property an individual? – Yes
  5. Did the individual acquire the property to hold or use exclusively as their place of residence, or the place of residence of another individual who is related to, a former spouse of, or a former common-law partner of the individual? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:

  • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act  (ETA)
  • Subsection 190(1) of the ETA deems the person to be a builder of the complex

REFERENCE:

  • Paragraph 190(1)(f) of the ETA makes an exception in this case so that the person is not deemed to be a builder of the complex

  • Subsection 190(1) of the ETA deems the person to be a builder of the complex

GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.3 - Residential real property - Deemed supplies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Lease of residential property

Is the rental of the residential complex (or residential unit in a residential complex) to be used by an individual?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Lease of residential property
  4. Is the rental of the residential complex (or residential unit in a residential complex) to be used by an individual? – Yes

Is the rent for occupancy (or right of occupancy) for a period of at least one month to the same individual?

A period of occupancy is a period of continuous occupancy by the same individual, notwithstanding that the rental may be on a daily or weekly basis.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property

Is the cost for the place of residence $20 or less per day?

  2. What is being supplied? – Real property

Section 6 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

ACT:

Section 6 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.2 - Residential real property - Rentals

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Appropriation for personal use

Does the appropriation apply to the non-residential portion of a building which is owned by an individual?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Appropriation for personal use
  4. Does the appropriation apply to the non-residential portion of a building which is owned by an individual? – Yes

Is that building already used primarily (more than 50%) as the individual's place of residence?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Appropriation for personal use
  4. Does the appropriation apply to the non-residential portion of a building which is owned by an individual? – Yes
  5. Is that building already used primarily (more than 50%) as the individual's place of residence? – Yes

RESULT:

Subsection 190(2) of the ETA does not deem a sale of the property to have occured.

The change-in-use rules in either subsections 207(1) or 207(2) of the ETA may also apply and deem a taxable supply by way of sale. 

ACT:

  • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act  (ETA)
  • Subsection 190(2) of the ETA
  • Subsections 207(1) or 207(2) of the ETA

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.3 - Residential real property - Deemed supplies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Appropriation for personal use
  4. Does the appropriation apply to the non-residential portion of a building which is owned by an individual? – Yes
  5. Is that building already used primarily (more than 50%) as the individual's place of residence? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% on the fair market value of the property (in other words, there is a deemed sale) where all of the following apply:

  • the individual appropriates real property for the personal use and enjoyment of the individual, a related individual, a former spouse or, a former common-law partner of the individual
  • the property was held for supply, or was capital property for use in a business or a commercial activity of the individual, immediately before the appropriation
  • the property was not a residential complex

NOTE:

The change-in-use rules in either subsections 207(1) or 207(2) of the ETA may also apply and deem a taxable supply by way of sale. However, double taxation is avoided because the formula for calculating the GST/HST liability under subsections 207(1) or 207(2) subtracts any GST/HST deemed collected under section 190.

ACT:

  • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act  (ETA)
  • Subsection 190(2) of the ETA

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.3 - Residential real property - Deemed supplies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Appropriation for personal use
  4. Does the appropriation apply to the non-residential portion of a building which is owned by an individual? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% on the fair market value of the property (in other words, there is a deemed sale) where all of the following apply:

  • the individual appropriates real property for the personal use and enjoyment of the individual, a related individual, a former spouse or, a former common-law partner of the individual
  • the property was held for supply, or was capital property for use in a business or a commercial activity of the individual, immediately before the appropriation
  • the property was not a residential complex

NOTE:

The change-in-use rules in either subsections 207(1) or 207(2) of the ETA may also apply and deem a taxable supply by way of sale. However, double taxation is avoided because the formula for calculating the GST/HST liability under subsections 207(1) or 207(2) subtracts any GST/HST deemed collected under section 190.

ACT:

  • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act  (ETA)
  • Subsection 190(2) of the ETA

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.3 - Residential real property - Deemed supplies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Lease of commercial real property

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:

Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act does not exempt the lease of commercial real property except in certain situations involving a supplier that is a public service body

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.4.1, Commercial Real Property - Sales and Rentals

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Services in relation to real property

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:

There are no provisions in Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act that would make the supply of services in relation to real property GST/HST exempt.

There are no provisions in Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act that would make the supply of services in relation to real property zero-rated for GST/HST purposes.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of vacant land (other than farmland)

Who is selling the vacant land?

  • Partnership or corporation
  • Individual or personal trust
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of vacant land (other than farmland)
  4. Who is selling the vacant land? – Partnership or corporation

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:

Paragraph 9(2)(c) of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act does not exempt the sale of vacant land if it is not sold by an individual or personal trust

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.5, Land and Associated Real Property

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of vacant land (other than farmland)
  4. Who is selling the vacant land? – Individual or personal trust

Was the vacant land sold to a relative for their personal use and enjoyment?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of vacant land (other than farmland)
  4. Who is selling the vacant land? – Individual or personal trust
  5. Was the vacant land sold to a relative for their personal use and enjoyment? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:

Paragraph 9(2)(c) of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.5, Land and Associated Real Property

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of vacant land (other than farmland)
  4. Who is selling the vacant land? – Individual or personal trust
  5. Was the vacant land sold to a relative for their personal use and enjoyment? – No

Did the seller subdivide or sever the land into parts?

Exception for expropriation:

For this rule, a part of a parcel of land that the individual, trust or settlor supplies to a person who has the right to acquire it by expropriation, and the remainder of that parcel, are deemed not to have been subdivided or severed from each other by the individual, trust or settlor.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of vacant land (other than farmland)
  4. Who is selling the vacant land? – Individual or personal trust
  5. Was the vacant land sold to a relative for their personal use and enjoyment? – No
  6. Did the seller subdivide or sever the land into parts? – Yes

Did the seller either sever the land into more than 2 parts and or did the seller previously sever it from another parcel?

Exception for expropriation

For this rule, a part of a parcel of land that the individual, trust or settlor supplies to a person who has the right to acquire it by expropriation, and the remainder of that parcel, are deemed not to have been subdivided or severed from each other by the individual, trust or settlor.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of vacant land (other than farmland)
  4. Who is selling the vacant land? – Individual or personal trust
  5. Was the vacant land sold to a relative for their personal use and enjoyment? – No
  6. Did the seller subdivide or sever the land into parts? – Yes
  7. Did the seller either sever the land into more than 2 parts and or did the seller previously sever it from another parcel? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:

Paragraph 9(2)(c) of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act does not exempt the sale of vacant land in this situation

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.5, Land and Associated Real Property

EXAMPLE:

Mr. Acres at one time owned a three-hectare parcel of land in Ontario. In 2012, he subdivided that parcel into one two-hectare lot and one one-hectare lot. He sold the one-hectare lot at that time. Since subparagraph 9(2)(c)(i) of Part I of Schedule V provides that a supply of a part of a parcel of land by an individual is exempt if the parcel is subdivided or severed into only two parts and if the originating parcel had not been subdivided or severed from another parcel, the sale of that one-hectare lot was exempt.

In January 2020, Mr. Acres subdivided the remaining two-hectare lot into two lots of one hectare each and sold those lots to people who are not related to him. Until that sale, the vacant land had been used primarily for Mr. Acres' personal use and enjoyment.

Since these one-hectare lots were produced by the further severance of the two-hectare lot which had itself been severed from the original three-hectare parcel, his sale of these one-hectare lots to people who are not related to him is GST/HST taxable at 13%.

Even though there is a gap in time in this example between the first subdivision and the second, the rules found in subparagraph 9(2)(c)(i) made the January 2020 sale of the remaining lots taxable.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of vacant land (other than farmland)
  4. Who is selling the vacant land? – Individual or personal trust
  5. Was the vacant land sold to a relative for their personal use and enjoyment? – No
  6. Did the seller subdivide or sever the land into parts? – Yes
  7. Did the seller either sever the land into more than 2 parts and or did the seller previously sever it from another parcel? – No

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:

Paragraph 9(2)(c) of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.5, Land and Associated Real Property

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of vacant land (other than farmland)
  4. Who is selling the vacant land? – Individual or personal trust
  5. Was the vacant land sold to a relative for their personal use and enjoyment? – No
  6. Did the seller subdivide or sever the land into parts? – No

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:

Paragraph 9(2)(c) of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.5, Land and Associated Real Property

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Lease of vacant land (other than farmland)

Is the lease, licence or similar arrangement based on a sharecrop agreement?

An example of a sharecrop agreement is when one farmer rents farmland to another for a percentage of the land's farm production.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Lease of vacant land (other than farmland)
  4. Is the lease, licence or similar arrangement based on a sharecrop agreement? – Yes

RESULT:

Zero-rated to the extent that the consideration for the lease of the land is a share of the farmland's production of zero-rated crops. Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% for any lease payment that is not for a share of zero-rated crops.

ACT:

Section 9 of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCES:

  • GST/HST Memorandum 19.5, Land and Associated Real Property
  • GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and Fishing


EXAMPLE:

A farmer rents farmland in Alberta to another farmer for $2,500 plus one-third of the land's farm production (which is a zero-rated crop). The GST is to be charged only on the $2,500 payment.

GST of 5% would also apply to any other consideration given for the lease of the land (other than a share in a crop the supply of which would be zero-rated).

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Lease of vacant land (other than farmland)
  4. Is the lease, licence or similar arrangement based on a sharecrop agreement? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:

All supplies of land by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement are taxable unless specifically exempted. Exempt supplies of real property are listed under Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act. There are no provisions in Part I of Schedule V that would make this supply zero-rated for GST/HST purposes.

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.5, Land and Associated Real Property

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Merger or amalgamation (transfer of real property)

RESULT:

GST/HST does not apply to the transfer of real property by a predecessor corporation to a new corporation if two or more corporations (the predecessor corporations) are merged or amalgamated to form one corporation (the new corporation) other than by the purchase of property by one corporation or the wind-up of one corporation. The transfer is deemed not to be a supply.

ACT:

Section 271 of the Excise Tax Act 

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.4.1 - Commercial real property - Sales

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of commercial real property (other than farmland)

Which best describes the sale of the commercial real property?

  • Finished - Mixed-used property (commercial and residential)
  • Finished - Leasehold interest/Assignment of commercial lease
  • Finished - None of the above
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of commercial real property (other than farmland)
  4. Which best describes the sale of the commercial real property? – Finished - Mixed-used property (commercial and residential)

RESULT:

For mixed-use real property, the  commercial portion being sold is deemed to be a separate supply than the residential portion. For the tax status of each portion, if it would have been exempt when sold on its own, that portion will be exempt when sold together.

The tax status for the commercial portion is taxable in the most common situations. This includes property sold by an individual or personal trust where:

  • immediately before the time ownership or possession of the property is transferred, the property is capital property used primarily (more than 50%) in a business carried on by the individual or personal trust with a reasonable expectation of profit
  • the sale is made in the course of a business of the individual or personal trust
  • the sale is made in the course of an adventure or concern in the nature of trade where the individual or personal trust has elected to have the sale treated as a taxable supply.

There are also certain situations where the sale of the commercial portion would be GST/HST exempt.

ACT:

  • Subsection 136(2) of the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Paragraph 9(2)(a) of Part 1 of Schedule V to the ETA

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.4.1 - Commercial real property - Sales

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of commercial real property (other than farmland)
  4. Which best describes the sale of the commercial real property? – Finished - Leasehold interest/Assignment of commercial lease

DEFINITION:

A leasehold interest is real property. For example, a building owner leases the building to a person and under the terms of the lease the person is entitled to assign the leasehold interest to a third party for consideration. Such an assignment is considered to be a sale of real property since a lessee that transfers its leasehold interest to a third party is transferring the ownership of the real property (in other words, the ownership of the leasehold interest) and therefore is making a sale of real property. The assignor in such a case is subject to the same provisions in respect of GST/HST obligations and entitlements that govern any other sale of real property.

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:

Subsection 221(2) of the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.4.1 - Commercial real property - Sales

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of commercial real property (other than farmland)
  4. Which best describes the sale of the commercial real property? – Finished - None of the above

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:

Paragraph 9(2)(a) of Part I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:

GST/HST Memorandum 19.4.1 - Commercial real property - Sales

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

Certain sections of the Excise Tax Act deem a transfer of the ownership of real property to either:

  • not be a supply
  • be a supply made for no consideration.

Since under section 165 (imposition of tax), GST/HST is calculated as a percentage of the consideration for the supply, if there is no supply or no consideration for the supply, there is no tax.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks

Which best describes the food or drink?

Most supplies of basic groceries (food and drinks intended for human consumption) are zero-rated.

Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act is the source of the zero-rating rules for food and drinks:

  • zero-rated, if none of the exceptions in paragraphs 1(a) through (q) apply
  • taxable at 5%, 13%, or 15% if any of the exceptions listed in paragraphs 1(a) through (q) apply

Section 2 of Part III of Schedule VI is the source of the zero-rating rules for unbottled water.

  • Supplements
  • Nuts or seeds
  • Cereals or grains
  • Fruits or vegetables
  • Candy or similar items
  • Meat, poultry, fish or eggs
  • Ingredients or similar items
  • Sold through a vending machine
  • Chips, popcorn or similar items
  • Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  • Cannabis products
  • Breads, cakes, pastries or similar items
  • Protein bars, chocolate bars or snack bars
  • Pudding, ice cream, yogurt or similar items
  • Drinks - syrups, crystals, powders or tea bags
  • Catering, restaurant or other immediate consumption
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Supplements

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

EXCEPTION: For zero-rated status of meal replacement bars and nutritional supplement bars, see bars.

ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act does not zero-rate dietary supplements because, although they may contain some essential nutritional elements, they are not considered to be basic groceries.

EXAMPLES:  Dietary supplements generally taken for their therapeutic or beneficial effects, such as:

  • vitamins
  • minerals
  • tonics
  • fibre
  • protein powders
  • herbal supplements

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Nuts or seeds

Which best describes the grocery item?

  • Mixtures of only nuts
  • Salted nuts or seeds (or similar flavours)
  • Mixtures of nuts with seeds or dried fruits
  • Sweetened nuts or seeds (naturally or artificially)
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Nuts or seeds
  4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Mixtures of only nuts

Are the mixed nuts in their natural state?

Natural state, for these purposes, means they have not been further processed than washed and cleaned. Nuts that have been seasoned, roasted or shelled are not considered to be in their natural state.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Nuts or seeds
  4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Mixtures of only nuts
  5. Are the mixed nuts in their natural state? – Yes

RESULT: Zero-rated

ACT: Paragraph 1(i) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Nuts or seeds
  4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Mixtures of only nuts
  5. Are the mixed nuts in their natural state? – No

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT: Paragraph 1(i) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries.

EXAMPLES: Mixed nuts that are:

  • roasted
  • seasoned
  • shelled

  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Nuts or seeds
  4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Salted nuts or seeds (or similar flavours)

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT: Paragraph 1(g) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries.

EXAMPLES:

  • cajun flavoured nuts
  • barbeque flavoured nuts
  • salted nuts

  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Nuts or seeds
  4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Mixtures of nuts with seeds or dried fruits

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

EXCEPTION: Any mixture that is sold primarily as a breakfast cereal is zero-rated

ACT: Paragraph 1(i) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries.

EXAMPLE:

  • trail mix

  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Nuts or seeds
  4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Sweetened nuts or seeds (naturally or artificially)

ACT: Paragraph 1(e) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries.

EXAMPLES: Nuts or seeds coated or treated with:

  • candy
  • chocolate
  • molasses
  • sugar
  • syrup

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Cereals or grains

RESULT: Zero-rated

ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

EXAMPLES: Grains or flour, whether sold in bulk or packaged, such as:

  • rice
  • wheat
  • oats
  • barley

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Fruits or vegetables

Which best describes the grocery item?

Salad kits: A package containing ingredients for a salad is not considered to be a salad for purposes of the GST/HST if the ingredients are not mixed (such as a package containing lettuce, croutons and dressing where the ingredients are in separate containers) and they require mixing by the consumer.

Stir-fry vegetables: Supplies of mixed, cut vegetables which are packaged and promoted as a "stir-fry" or "chop suey mix" as well as a supply of mixed vegetable sprouts are not considered salads.

  • Salad
  • Salad kit
  • Frozen fruit or vegetables
  • Other fresh fruits or vegetables
  • Fruit or vegetable platters (fresh or frozen)
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Fruits or vegetables
  4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Salad

Is the salad either vacuum-sealed or canned?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Fruits or vegetables
  4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Salad
  5. Is the salad either vacuum-sealed or canned? – Yes

RESULT: Zero-rated

ACT: Paragraph 1(o.1) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Fruits or vegetables
  4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Salad
  5. Is the salad either vacuum-sealed or canned? – No

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT: Paragraph 1(o.1) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Fruits or vegetables
  4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Salad kit

RESULT: Zero-rated, if:

  • all ingredients are packaged in separate compartments
  • ingredients need to be mixed by the consumer

ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Fruits or vegetables
  4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Frozen fruit or vegetables

RESULT: Zero-rated

EXCEPTION: Frozen fruit or vegetables on a platter

  • candies

ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

EXAMPLES: May be sold:

  • fresh
  • frozen
  • canned
  • vacuum sealed

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Ingredients or similar items

RESULT: Zero-rated

EXCEPTIONS (taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%):

  • food additives ethyl alcohol and other alcohols
  • propane and carbon dioxide (CO2)
  • ingredients packaged and promoted for non-food use

ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

EXAMPLES:

  • ingredients to be used in the preparation of food and beverages for human consumption
  • cooking wines sold and represented as condiments

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Sold through a vending machine

Which best describes the vending machine sale of food or drinks?

  • Unbottled water
  • Bought for 25¢ or less (single coin)
  • None of the above
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Sold through a vending machine
  4. Which best describes the vending machine sale of food or drinks? – Unbottled water

Which quantity is sold?

  • 600 ml or more
  • Less than 600 ml
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Sold through a vending machine
  4. Which best describes the vending machine sale of food or drinks? – Unbottled water
  5. Which quantity is sold? – 600 ml or more

RESULT: Zero-rated

Act: Section 2 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Sold through a vending machine
  4. Which best describes the vending machine sale of food or drinks? – Unbottled water
  5. Which quantity is sold? – Less than 600 ml

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

Act:

  • Paragraph 1(r) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act excludes it from zero-rating
  • Section 2 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act does not zero-rate single serving quantities

 

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Sold through a vending machine
  4. Which best describes the vending machine sale of food or drinks? – Bought for 25¢ or less (single coin)

RESULT: Tax is calculated to be zero

ACT: Subsection 165.1(2) of the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Sold through a vending machine
  4. Which best describes the vending machine sale of food or drinks? – None of the above

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT: Paragraph 1(p) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

EXAMPLES: Food or drinks that are normally zero-rated when not purchased through a vending machine, such as:

  • a single serving of unflavoured white milk
  • an apple

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Chips, popcorn or similar items

Which best describes the snack food?

  • Crackers
  • Popcorn - bagged
  • Popcorn - unpopped kernals
  • Trail mix and other snack mixtures
  • Chips, crisps, puffs and similar items

  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Chips, popcorn or similar items
  4. Which best describes the snack food? – Crackers

  • chips
  • crisps
  • puffs
  • any combination of nuts, seeds, dried fruit and toasted oats

  • Alcohol
  • Bottled water

  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks

  4. Which best describes the drink? – Alcohol

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

EXCEPTION: Cooking wines when sold and represented as condiments are zero-rated

ACT: Paragraph 1(a) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act excludes them from zero-rating

REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

EXAMPLES:

  • wine
  • beer
  • spirits
  • malt liquor
  • any other drink with alcohol
  • de-alcoholised beer
  • de-alcoholised wine

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Bottled water

How is the water packaged?

Single serving - its meaning depends on the size (generally less than 600 ml) but also its type of packaging and marketing.

  • Single serving
  • Larger than single serving
  • Multiple single servings (prepackaged)
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Bottled water
  5. How is the water packaged? – Single serving

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks

ACT: Paragraph 1(n) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Bottled water
  5. How is the water packaged? – Multiple single servings (prepackaged)

RESULT: Zero-rated

REQUIREMENTS: To qualify for zero-rating, the water must be prepackaged in multiples of 2 or more (regardless of size) by the producer or manufacturer

ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
  
REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Carbonated drinks

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

EXCEPTION: Post-mix for a soda fountain that contains other ingredients for a carbonated beverage, but does not contain CO2, is zero-rated.

ACT:  Paragraph 1(c) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

  • pop
  • mineral water
  • soda water

  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Milk - flavoured

How is the flavoured milk packaged?

Includes milk flavoured with strawberry or other fruits, chocolate, vanilla, flavoured fermented milk drinks such as kefir, and other flavoured milk-based drinks.

Single serving - its meaning depends on the size (generally less than 600 ml) but also its type of packaging and marketing.

  • Single serving
  • Larger than single serving
  • Multiple single servings (prepackaged)

  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks

ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
  
REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Milk - unflavoured

RESULT: Zero-rated

ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Juice (fruit or vegetable)

How is the juice packaged?

To be considered a fruit juice, the drink must contain at least 25% natural fruit juice by volume.

If the drink is a blend of fruits and vegetables, the fruit portion must contain at least 25% natural fruit juice.

To be considered a vegetable juice, there is no similar requirement, only that the juice not be fruit-flavoured.

Single serving - its meaning depends on the size (generally less than 600 ml) but also its type of packaging and marketing. For example, a 540 ml sealed can of vegetable juice isn’t considered a single serving. Those cans have no built-in opening devices and are not marketed and promoted as single servings.

  • Single serving
  • Frozen concentrate
  • Non-frozen concentrate
  • Larger than single serving
  • Multiple single servings (prepackaged)
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Juice (fruit or vegetable)
  5. How is the juice packaged? – Single serving

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT: Paragraph 1(n) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Juice (fruit or vegetable)
  5. How is the juice packaged? – Frozen concentrate

RESULT: Zero-rated if the percentage of fruit juice in the concentrate is 25% or more by volume (not the percentage of fruit juice in the beverage when reconstituted)

ACT: Paragraph 1(d) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Juice (fruit or vegetable)
  5. How is the juice packaged? – Non-frozen concentrate

RESULT: Zero-rated if the percentage of fruit juice is 25% or more by volume in the reconstituted drink (after water is added to the product to create a drink according to instructions on the package)

ACT: Paragraph 1(d) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Juice (fruit or vegetable)
  5. How is the juice packaged? – Larger than single serving

RESULT: Zero-rated

ACT: Paragraph 1(n) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Juice (fruit or vegetable)
  5. How is the juice packaged? – Multiple single servings (prepackaged)

RESULT: Zero-rated

REQUIREMENTS: To qualify for zero-rating, the juice must be prepackaged in multiples of 2 or more (regardless of size) by the producer or manufacturer

ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
  
REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Fruit-flavoured (not juice)

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

EXCEPTIONS:

  • Fruit-flavoured tea (for example, lemon-flavoured iced tea) is zero-rated
  • For fruit-flavoured milk, see Milk - flavoured.


ACT: Paragraph 1(d) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

EXAMPLES: Fruit-flavoured drinks (if the natural fruit juice makes up less than 25% of the drink) sold in:

  • bottles
  • cans
  • cartons
  • drink boxes

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Non-dairy milk alternatives

How is the drink packaged?

Includes soy, rice and nut-based drinks sold as milk alternatives.

For fruit-flavoured drinks (for example, strawberry-flavoured soy drink), see Fruit-flavoured (not juice).

Single serving - its meaning depends on the size (generally less than 600 ml) but also its type of packaging and marketing.

  • Single serving
  • Larger than single serving
  • Multiple single servings (prepackaged)
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Non-dairy milk alternatives
  5. How is the drink packaged? – Single serving

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT: Paragraph 1(n) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Non-dairy milk alternatives
  5. How is the drink packaged? – Larger than single serving

RESULT: Zero-rated

ACT: Paragraph 1(n) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Non-dairy milk alternatives
  5. How is the drink packaged? – Multiple single servings (prepackaged)

RESULT: Zero-rated

REQUIREMENTS: To qualify for zero-rating, the drink must be prepackaged in multiples of 2 or more (regardless of size) by the producer or manufacturer

ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
  
REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - bottled or similar packaging
  4. Which best describes the drink? – Prepared and prepackaged for consumption by babies

RESULT: Zero-rated, regardless of serving size and packaging format

ACT: Paragraph 1(n) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Cannabis products

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT: Paragraph 1(b) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Breads, cakes, pastries or similar items

Which best describes the baked good?

  • Bread, bun, bagel, croissant or similar item
  • Cake, pie, cookie, doughnut, brownie or other sweetened baked good
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Breads, cakes, pastries or similar items
  4. Which best describes the baked good? – Bread, bun, bagel, croissant or similar item

Does the item have a sweetened filling or a sweetened coating?

Sweetened filling - includes any sweetening ingredients (other than unsweetened fruit) added as a filling, but does not include sweetened products added only as a catalyst for leavening agents (known as yeast foods).

Sweetened coating - includes any icing, sugar or sweetened topping applied to the surface of a product before, during or after processing.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Breads, cakes, pastries or similar items
  4. Which best describes the baked good? – Bread, bun, bagel, croissant or similar item
  5. Does the item have a sweetened filling or a sweetened coating? – Yes

Which best describes the sweetened baked good?

  • Single serving
  • Six or more single servings
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Breads, cakes, pastries or similar items
  4. Which best describes the baked good? – Bread, bun, bagel, croissant or similar item
  5. Does the item have a sweetened filling or a sweetened coating? – Yes
  6. Which best describes the sweetened baked good? – Single serving

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT: Paragraph 1(m) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Breads, cakes, pastries or similar items
  4. Which best describes the baked good? – Bread, bun, bagel, croissant or similar item
  5. Does the item have a sweetened filling or a sweetened coating? – Yes
  6. Which best describes the sweetened baked good? – Six or more single servings

RESULT: Zero-rated

  5. Does the item have a sweetened filling or a sweetened coating? – No

RESULT: Zero-rated

ACT: Paragraph 1(m) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Breads, cakes, pastries or similar items
  4. Which best describes the baked good? – Cake, pie, cookie, doughnut, brownie or other sweetened baked good

Which best describes the sweetened baked good?

If the item does not have a sweetened coating or a sweetened filling, see Bread, bun, bagel, croissant or similar item.

Sweetened filling - includes any sweetening ingredients (other than unsweetened fruit) added as a filling, but does not include sweetened products added only as a catalyst for leavening agents (known as yeast foods).

Sweetened coating - includes any icing, sugar or sweetened topping applied to the surface of a product before, during or after processing.

  • Single serving
  • Six or more single servings
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Breads, cakes, pastries or similar items
  4. Which best describes the baked good? – Cake, pie, cookie, doughnut, brownie or other sweetened baked good
  5. Which best describes the sweetened baked good? – Single serving

RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT: Paragraph 1(m) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Breads, cakes, pastries or similar items
  4. Which best describes the baked good? – Cake, pie, cookie, doughnut, brownie or other sweetened baked good
  5. Which best describes the sweetened baked good? – Six or more single servings

RESULT: Zero-rated

ACT: Paragraph 1(m) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Protein bars, chocolate bars or snack bars

Which best describes the bars?

Meal replacement bars are bars that qualify as meal replacements or nutritional supplements under the Food and Drugs Act and Regulations.

Cereal bars and muffin bars - A cereal bar with a fruit filling is generally not considered to be a fruit bar.

  • Meal replacement bars
  • Cereal bars and muffin bars
  • Energy bars and protein bars
  • Granola bars, fruit bars or nut bars
  • Chocolate bars other other candy bars
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Protein bars, chocolate bars or snack bars
  4. Which best describes the bars? – Meal replacement bars

RESULT: Zero-rated

ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:

  • GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries
  • GST/HST Info Sheet GI-020, Bars

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Protein bars, chocolate bars or snack bars
  4. Which best describes the bars? – Cereal bars and muffin bars

How are the bars packaged?

  • Six or more bars in a box
  • Sold individually (or less than six bars in a box)

  2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
  3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Protein bars, chocolate bars or snack bars
  4. Which best describes the bars? – Cereal bars and muffin bars
  5. How are the bars packaged? – Six or more bars in a box

ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
