  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale of tangible personal property (goods)
  3. Is the NPO selling the goods at their direct cost? – No
  4. Is the NPO selling excisable goods? – No
  5. Does the NPO carry on the business of selling such goods? – No
  6. Are all of the salespersons volunteers? – No

RESULT:

No GST/HST exemption exists for the supply in section 4 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA). If no other legislation exempts or zero-rates the supply, the sale would be taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%.

ACT:
Paragraph 4(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Supply for the benefit of organized labour

Who is the supply made to?

  • Another NPO established primarily for the benefit of organized labour
  • Trade union (or association or body referred to in paragraphs 189(a) to (c) that is a member of or affiliated with the organization)
  • None of the above
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Supply for the benefit of organized labour
  3. Who is the supply made to? – Another NPO established primarily for the benefit of organized labour

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
Section 26 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Supply for the benefit of organized labour
  3. Who is the supply made to? – Trade union (or association or body referred to in paragraphs 189(a) to (c) that is a member of or affiliated with the organization)

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
  • Section 26 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Paragraphs 189(a) to (c) of the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Supply for the benefit of organized labour
  3. Who is the supply made to? – None of the above

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Section 26 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Membership to maintain a professional status

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt if the membership is required to maintain a professional status recognized by statute, except where the NPO supplier has made a valid election using Form GST24.

ACT:
Section 18 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – 90% or more supplies made for no consideration

RESULT:

Supplies are GST/HST exempt, other than supplies of:
  • parking spaces by lease, licence or similar arrangement in the course of a business carried on by a organization (see the "Real property" subtopic for rules relating to the tax status of parking spaces)
  • blood or blood derivatives (as those supplies are zero-rated under Schedule VI) 
ACT:
  • Section 10 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Schedule VI to the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)

Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property?

  • Lease of parking space
  • Short-term accommodation
  • Sale of a residential complex
  • Supply was deemed to be made for GST/HST purposes
  • Lease or licence (other than short term accommodation)
  • Sale of real property to an individual or personal trust
  • Sale or lease of real property used primarily in the NPO's commercial activities
  • Real property the last supply of which to the NPO was deemed to have been made under subsection 183(1)
  • A Form GST26 election is in effect (to have an exempt supply of real property treated as a taxable supply)
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Lease of parking space

Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Lease of parking space
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes

For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital?

Specified parking area for a parking space means all of the parking spaces that could be chosen for use in parking under the agreement for the supply of the parking space if all of those parking spaces were vacant and none were reserved for specific users.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Lease of parking space
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes

Which of the following apply?

The GST/HST exemption for use of a parking space is generally intended for individuals going to a public hospital as a patient or a visitor, but the overall intended use of the specified parking area impacts the exemption.

  • A Form GST26 election is in effect (to have an exempt supply of real property treated as a taxable supply)
  • 90% or more of the parking spaces are reserved for persons who are not individuals accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity
  • Advance agreement for parking space to be available for more than 24 hours and for its use by persons who are not individuals accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity
  • The price for, or ability to use, the parking space is conditional on the parking space being used by persons who are not individuals accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity
  • None of the above
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Lease of parking space
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  6. Which of the following apply? – A Form GST26 election is in effect (to have an exempt supply of real property treated as a taxable supply)

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Paragraph 25.1(c) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 211 of the ETA

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
  • Form GST26, Election or Revocation of an Election by a Public Service Body to Have an Exempt Supply of Real Property Treated as a Taxable Supply
  • GST/HST Notice 285, Application of the GST/HST to Supplies of Parking by Charities and Public Sector Bodies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Lease of parking space
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  6. Which of the following apply? – 90% or more of the parking spaces are reserved for persons who are not individuals accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25.1(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
GST/HST Notice 285, Application of the GST/HST to Supplies of Parking by Charities and Public Sector Bodies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Lease of parking space
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  6. Which of the following apply? – Advance agreement for parking space to be available for more than 24 hours and for its use by persons who are not individuals accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25.1(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
GST/HST Notice 285, Application of the GST/HST to Supplies of Parking by Charities and Public Sector Bodies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Lease of parking space
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  6. Which of the following apply? – The price for, or ability to use, the parking space is conditional on the parking space being used by persons who are not individuals accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25.1(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
GST/HST Notice 285, Application of the GST/HST to Supplies of Parking by Charities and Public Sector Bodies

EXAMPLE:
A hospital in Calgary, Alberta charges their employees a reduced rate to park in their lot. Hospital visitors are charged the full price to park in the same lot. The hospital would charge GST on the parking spaces.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Lease of parking space
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  6. Which of the following apply? – None of the above

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
Section 25.1 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Lease of parking space
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25.1(a) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

EXAMPLE:
A parking lot in Windsor, Ontario is shared and available for someone to access a public hospital or various nearby businesses. There are no designated areas identifying which of the parking spaces are for the hospital and which are for the other businesses. 13% HST would be charged on the parking space.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Lease of parking space
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25(h) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Short-term accommodation

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Paragraph 25(e) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Subsection 123(1) of the ETA

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
Short-term accommodation means a period of occupancy or a right of occupancy by an individual in a residential complex or a residential unit that is supplied by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement for a period of less than one month where such occupation is for use as a place of residence or lodging. The period of occupancy is calculated as a period where the same individual is given continuous occupancy, notwithstanding that the rental may be on a daily or weekly basis.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Sale of a residential complex

RESULT:

Although removed from the general GST/HST exemption for real property found in section 25 of Part VI of Schedule V, the sale may be GST/HST exempt for other reasons. For more information for this type of supply, see the "Real property" subtopic under the category "Most businesses".

ACT:
  • Paragraph 25(a) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Part I of Schedule V to the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Supply was deemed to be made for GST/HST purposes

Was the supply only deemed to have been made because of lease interval rules found in section 136.1?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Supply was deemed to be made for GST/HST purposes
  4. Was the supply only deemed to have been made because of lease interval rules found in section 136.1? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt
 
ACT:
  • Paragraph 25(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 136.1 of the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Supply was deemed to be made for GST/HST purposes
  4. Was the supply only deemed to have been made because of lease interval rules found in section 136.1? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%
 
ACT:
Paragraph 25(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Lease or licence (other than short term accommodation)

Which best describes the supply of real property?

Short-term accommodation means a period of occupancy or a right of occupancy by an individual in a residential complex or a residential unit that is supplied by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement for a period of less than one month where such occupation is for use as a place of residence or lodging. The period of occupancy is calculated as a period where the same individual is given continuous occupancy, notwithstanding that the rental may be on a daily or weekly basis.

  • Licence
  • Lease for continuous possession of one month or more
  • Lease for continuous possession of less than one month
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Lease or licence (other than short term accommodation)
  4. Which best describes the supply of real property? – Licence

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Paragraph 25(f) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Subsection 123(1) of the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Lease or licence (other than short term accommodation)
  4. Which best describes the supply of real property? – Lease for continuous possession of one month or more

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt unless the specific type of supply is removed for a different reason from the general exemption for supplies of real property by an NPO 

ACT:
Paragraph 25(f) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Lease or licence (other than short term accommodation)
  4. Which best describes the supply of real property? – Lease for continuous possession of less than one month

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% if the supply is made in the course of a business carried on by the NPO

ACT:
  • Paragraph 25(f) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Subsection 123(1) of the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)

  • No

  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)

Was the property used primarily in commercial activities of the NPO immediately before tax would be payable if it were a taxable sale?

  • Yes
  • No

  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Sale of real property to an individual or personal trust

  5. Was the property used primarily in commercial activities of the NPO immediately before tax would be payable if it were a taxable sale? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraphs 25(c) and 25(d) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Sale of real property to an individual or personal trust
  4. Is there a structure on the property that was used by the NPO as an office or in the course of either commercial activities or of making exempt supplies? – Yes
  5. Was the property used primarily in commercial activities of the NPO immediately before tax would be payable if it were a taxable sale? – No

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt unless the specific type of supply is removed for a different reason from the general exemption for supplies of real property by an NPO

  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Sale of real property to an individual or personal trust

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25(c) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Sale or lease of real property used primarily in the NPO's commercial activities

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% if it was used more than 50% in the NPO's commercial activities immediately before tax would be payable if it were a taxable supply

ACT:
Paragraph 25(d) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)
  3. Which best describes the non-profit organization's supply of real property? – Real property the last supply of which to the NPO was deemed to have been made under subsection 183(1)

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25(i) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Sale or lease of real property (including parking)

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Paragraph 25.1(c) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 211 of the ETA

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
  • Form GST26, Election or Revocation of an Election by a Public Service Boidy to Have an Exempt Supply of Real Property Treated as a Taxable Supply
  • GST/HST Notice 285, Application of the GST/HST to Supplies of Parking by Charities and Public Sector Bodies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Right to play or participate in a game of chance (other than an admission)

Is the supply a prescribed game of chance?

A prescribed game of chance is one that is conducted by one of the following persons:

  • the Atlantic Lottery Corporation
  • the British Columbia Lottery Corporation
  • the Manitoba Liquor and Lotteries Corporation
  • the Ontario Lottery and Gaming Corporation
  • la Société des loteries et courses du Québec
  • the Western Canada Lottery Corporation
  • the Interprovincial Lottery Corporation
  • the Alberta Gaming and Liquor Commission
  • the Saskatchewan Liquor and Gaming Authority
  • the Saskatchewan Gaming Corporation
  • the New Brunswick Lotteries and Gaming Corporation
  • the Nova Scotia Provincial Lotteries and Casino Corporation

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Right to play or participate in a game of chance (other than an admission)
  3. Is the supply a prescribed game of chance? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Section 5.1 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
  • Sections 3 and 4 of the Games of Chance (GST/HST) Regulations

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Right to play or participate in a game of chance (other than an admission)
  3. Is the supply a prescribed game of chance? – No

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
  • Section 5.1 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
  • Sections 3 and 4 of the Games of Chance (GST/HST) Regulations

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Supply deemed to be made by the institution under section 187 of the Excise Tax Act

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt
 
ACT:
Section 5.2 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Services sold for their direct cost

Did the NPO buy the service with the intention to sell it?

Overlay These scenarios show whether the service is taxable when made by a non-profit organization, except one that is determined by the Minister to be a municipality.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Services sold for their direct cost
  3. Did the NPO buy the service with the intention to sell it? – Yes

Is the total charge for the service the usual charge by the NPO for such services to such recipients?

Overlay Recipient in this case means the person who an agreement says must pay for the service. If there is no agreement, the recipient would be the person who must pay for the service

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Services sold for their direct cost
  3. Did the NPO buy the service with the intention to sell it? – Yes
  4. Is the total charge for the service the usual charge by the NPO for such services to such recipients? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt where the NPO sells the service at its direct cost. 
 
If the NPO does not charge any amount as GST/HST for the service, its direct cost would mean the charge isn't (and couldn't reasonably be) more than the NPO's cost for the service.
 
If the NPO charges any amount as GST/HST for the service, its direct cost would mean the charge for the service isn't (and couldn't reasonably be) the same as, or more than, the NPO's cost for the service. Their cost would be calculated without including any amount for GST/HST paid.

ACT:
Section 6 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Services sold for their direct cost
  3. Did the NPO buy the service with the intention to sell it? – Yes
  4. Is the total charge for the service the usual charge by the NPO for such services to such recipients? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% unless other legislation exempts or zero-rates the sale for a different reason.

ACT:
Section 6 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Services sold for their direct cost
  3. Did the NPO buy the service with the intention to sell it? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% unless other legislation exempts or zero-rates the sale for a different reason.

ACT:
Section 6 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Food, beverages or short-term accommodation supplied to relieve poverty, suffering or distress of individuals

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt if the supply is not for the purpose of fund-raising

ACT:
Section 14 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Membership (or other right) entitling person to supervision or instruction in recreational or athletic activity

Who is the membership intended to be provided primarily to?

  • Children 14 years old or younger
  • Underprivileged individuals or individuals with a disability
  • None of the above
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Membership (or other right) entitling person to supervision or instruction in recreational or athletic activity
  3. Who is the membership intended to be provided primarily to? – Children 14 years old or younger

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt if the supply is of a membership in, or services supplied as part of, a program established and operated by the NPO that consists of a series of supervised instructional classes or activities involving athletics, outdoor recreation, music, dance, arts, crafts or other hobbies or recreational pursuits where it may reasonably be expected that the program will be provided primarily to children 14 years of age or under, except where the program involves overnight supervision throughout a substantial portion of the program.
 
ACT:
Section 12 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Membership (or other right) entitling person to supervision or instruction in recreational or athletic activity
  3. Who is the membership intended to be provided primarily to? – Underprivileged individuals or individuals with a disability

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt if the supply is of a membership in, or services supplied as part of, a program established and operated by the NPO that consists of a series of supervised instructional classes or activities involving athletics, outdoor recreation, music, dance, arts, crafts or other hobbies or recreational pursuits where the program is provided primarily for underprivileged individuals or individuals with a disability.
  
ACT:
Section 12 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Membership (or other right) entitling person to supervision or instruction in recreational or athletic activity
  3. Who is the membership intended to be provided primarily to? – None of the above

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% unless the specific type of supply is exempted for a different reason
  
ACT:
Section 12 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Food or beverages supplied under a program to seniors, underprivileged individuals or individuals with a disability

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt when under a program established and operated for the purpose of providing prepared food to such individuals in their places of residence. Supplies of food or beverages made to the non-profit organization for the purpose of the program are also GST/HST exempt.

ACT:
Section 15 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Non-profit organization
  2. Which best describes what the non-profit organization is supplying? – Board and lodging or recreational services, at a recreational camp supplied to underprivileged individuals or individuals with a disability

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt when supplied under a program established and operated for the purpose of providing the board and lodging or services primarily to underprivileged individuals or individuals with a disability

ACT:
Section 13 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity

Which best describes the charity's activity?

Most supplies by charities are GST/HST exempt. Although, for income tax purposes, "charity” means a registered charity or a registered Canadian amateur athletic association, for GST/HST purposes, "charity" does not include a charity that is also:

  • a school authority
  • a public college
  • a university
  • a hospital authority, or
  • a local authority determined to be a municipality by the Minister of National Revenue.
Instead, public institution is the term for that type of charity. For the tax status of supplies by a public institution, see the subtopic "Municipality, university, school or hospital"

  • Admission
  • Real property
  • Exported supply
  • Services sold for their direct cost
  • Supply deemed to be made by the charity
  • Purely cosmetic service to an individual
  • 90% or more of their supplies made for no consideration
  • Personal property that was used in a commercial activity
  • Section 178.7, specified service supplied to a registrant
  • Tangible personal property (goods) sold for their direct cost
  • Right to play or participate in a game of chance (other than an admission)
  • Sale of personal property or a service in the course of a fundraising activity
  • Other supplies that would be zero-rated (taxable at 0%) if supplied by most businesses
  • Lease of personal property in conjunction with an exempt lease of real property by the charity
  • Supplies of performing artists to a person who makes taxable supplies admissions for the performance
  • Food, beverages or short-term accommodation supplied to relieve poverty, suffering or distress of individuals
  • Membership (or other right) entitling person to supervision or instruction in recreational or athletic activity
  • Food or beverages supplied under a program to seniors, underprivileged individuals or individuals with a disability
  • Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the charity for the purpose of making a sale of the property
  • Supply of designated municipal property, if the charity is a person designated to be a municipality for the purposes of section 259 of the Excise Tax Act
  • None of the above
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission

What is the admission in respect of?

  • Admission to a fund-raising event
  • Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
  • Place of amusement and the admission cost is not more than $1
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
  3. What is the admission in respect of? – Admission to a fund-raising event

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt where:
  • the supply is of an admission to a fund-raising dinner, ball, concert, show or like fund-raising event, and
  • part of the consideration for the supply may reasonably be regarded as an amount that is donated to the charity and in respect of which a receipt referred to in subsection 110.1(2) or 118.1(2) of the Income Tax Act may be issued (or could be issued if the recipient of the supply were an individual)
ACT:
  • Section 2 of Part V.1 of Sch V to Excise Tax Act
  • Subsections 110.1(2) and 118.1(2) of the Income Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
  3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1

Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
  3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
  4. Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – Yes

Are the functions (administrative, operating the game and taking the bets) performed exclusively by volunteers?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
  3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
  4. Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – Yes
  5. Are the functions (administrative, operating the game and taking the bets) performed exclusively by volunteers? – Yes

Is the place of amusement either a bingo or a casino?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
  3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
  4. Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – Yes
  5. Are the functions (administrative, operating the game and taking the bets) performed exclusively by volunteers? – Yes
  6. Is the place of amusement either a bingo or a casino? – Yes

Is the game conducted in premises or at a place, including any temporary structure, that is used primarily for the purposes of conducting gambling activities?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
  3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
  4. Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – Yes
  5. Are the functions (administrative, operating the game and taking the bets) performed exclusively by volunteers? – Yes
  6. Is the place of amusement either a bingo or a casino? – Yes
  7. Is the game conducted in premises or at a place, including any temporary structure, that is used primarily for the purposes of conducting gambling activities? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Sections 1 and 6 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
  3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
  4. Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – Yes
  5. Are the functions (administrative, operating the game and taking the bets) performed exclusively by volunteers? – Yes
  6. Is the place of amusement either a bingo or a casino? – Yes
  7. Is the game conducted in premises or at a place, including any temporary structure, that is used primarily for the purposes of conducting gambling activities? – No

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

  6. Is the place of amusement either a bingo or a casino? – No

ACT:
Sections 1 and 6 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity

  3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is not more than $1

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
Paragraph 1(e) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property

Which best describes the charity's supply of real property?

  • Sale of a residential complex
  • Supply of real property when a section 211 election is in effect
  • Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
  • Sale of real property recently used primarily in commercial activities of the charity
  • Sale of real property (that is not a residential complex) to an individual or a personal trust
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of a residential complex

Which best describes the residential property being sold?

  • Newly built home
  • Used owner-occupied home
  • Substantially renovated home
  • Mixed-used property (home and business)
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of a residential complex
  4. Which best describes the residential property being sold? – Newly built home

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Paragraph 1(j) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA) excludes the sale of a residential complex from the general exemption available to charities
  • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the ETA does not exempt the sale of a home by a builder 

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.1 - Residential real property - Sales

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of a residential complex
  4. Which best describes the residential property being sold? – Used owner-occupied home

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt when sold by someone other than the builder (even though the sale of a residential complex is removed from the general exempting provision that is specifically for charities). If substantial renovations have been completed, see the topic "Substantially renovated home" instead.
 
ACT:
  • Paragraph 1(j) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the ETA
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.1 - Residential real property - Sales

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of a residential complex
  4. Which best describes the residential property being sold? – Substantially renovated home

DEFINITION:

Substantial renovation - is generally when all of the interior of the existing building has been virtually removed or replaced (in other words, gutted) and, upon completion, the renovated or altered building is, or forms part of, a residential complex.

RESULT:
Generally taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Paragraph 1(j) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA) excludes the sale of a residential complex from the general exemption available to charities
  • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the ETA excludes the sale of a home by a builder from its GST/HST exemption
  • Subsection 123(1) of the ETA defines "builder"
  • Subsection 190(1) of the ETA deems a person that has substantially renovated a house to be a builder (in the most common circumstances)

REFERENCE:
  • GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.1 - Residential real property - Sales
  • GST/HST Memorandum 19.2 - Residential real property

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of a residential complex
  4. Which best describes the residential property being sold? – Mixed-used property (home and business)

RESULT:

The sale of the residential portion is deemed to be a separate supply than the remaining portion of the real property (for example, commercial real property). The general exemption available to charities excludes certain supplies of real property. However, if the either the residential or non-residential portion would have been exempt when sold on its own, it will be exempt when sold together with taxable real property.

ACT:
  • Paragraph 1(j) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA) excludes the sale of a residential complex from the general exemption available to charities
  • Paragraph 1(l) of Part V.1 of Schedule V excludes the sale of a residential complex from the general exemption available to charities
  • Subsection 136(2) of the ETA
  • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the ETA

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.1 - Residential real property - Sales

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Supply of real property when a section 211 election is in effect

RESULT:

GST/HST taxable

ACT:
  • Paragraph 1(m) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 211 of the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement

Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital?

NOTE:

If a charity supplies, for consideration, a parking space by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement in the course of a business they carry on, paragraph 1(o) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act removes the supply from its general GST/HST exemption for charities if:
  • at the time the supply is made, it is reasonable to expect that the specified parking area will be used, during that calendar year, primarily by individuals who are accessing a property of, or a facility or establishment operated by, a particular person that is a municipality, a school authority, a hospital authority, a public college or a university, and
  • any of the following conditions is met:
    • under the governing documents of the charity, the charity is expected to use a significant part of its income or assets for the benefit of one or more of those particular persons referred to above in the first bullet
    • the charity and any of those particular persons have entered into one or more agreements with each other or with other persons in respect of the use of parking spaces by the individuals referred to in the first bullet above
    • any particular person referred to in the first bullet above performs any function or activity in respect of supplies by the charity of parking spaces in the specified parking area in relation to the supply
However, being removed from the general exemption only makes the supply taxable if there is no other exempting provision. Section 7 of Part V.1 of Schedule V exempts certain types of supplies of a parking space by a charity that are made by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement and relate to access to a public hospital.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes

For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital?

Specified parking area for a parking space means all of the parking spaces that could be chosen for use in parking under the agreement for the supply of the parking space if all of those parking spaces were vacant and none were reserved for specific users.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes

Are 90% or more of the parking spaces in the specified parking area reserved for use by persons other than individuals accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  6. Are 90% or more of the parking spaces in the specified parking area reserved for use by persons other than individuals accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Paragraph 1(o) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Subparagraph 7(b)(i) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  6. Are 90% or more of the parking spaces in the specified parking area reserved for use by persons other than individuals accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No

Is the supply (or the amount of the consideration for the supply) conditional on the parking space being used by a person other than an individual accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  6. Are 90% or more of the parking spaces in the specified parking area reserved for use by persons other than individuals accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No
  7. Is the supply (or the amount of the consideration for the supply) conditional on the parking space being used by a person other than an individual accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Paragraph 1(o) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Subparagraph 7(b)(ii) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5.   6. Are 90% or more of the parking spaces in the specified parking area reserved for use by persons other than individuals accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No
  7. Is the supply (or the amount of the consideration for the supply) conditional on the parking space being used by a person other than an individual accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No

Was the agreement for the supply entered into in advance and, under its terms, is use of a parking space in the specified parking area made available for a total period of more than 24 hours and the use is to be by a person other than an individual accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  6. Are 90% or more of the parking spaces in the specified parking area reserved for use by persons other than individuals accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No
  7. Is the supply (or the amount of the consideration for the supply) conditional on the parking space being used by a person other than an individual accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No
  8. Was the agreement for the supply entered into in advance and, under its terms, is use of a parking space in the specified parking area made available for a total period of more than 24 hours and the use is to be by a person other than an individual accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Paragraph 1(o) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Subparagraph 7(b)(iii) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  6. Are 90% or more of the parking spaces in the specified parking area reserved for use by persons other than individuals accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No
  7. Is the supply (or the amount of the consideration for the supply) conditional on the parking space being used by a person other than an individual accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No
  8. Was a section 211 election made by the charity in effect for the property where the parking space is situated?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  6. Are 90% or more of the parking spaces in the specified parking area reserved for use by persons other than individuals accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No
  7. Is the supply (or the amount of the consideration for the supply) conditional on the parking space being used by a person other than an individual accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No
  8. Was the agreement for the supply entered into in advance and, under its terms, is use of a parking space in the specified parking area made available for a total period of more than 24 hours and the use is to be by a person other than an individual accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No
  9. Was a section 211 election made by the charity in effect for the property where the parking space is situated? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%. The time period for the election being in effect refers to the time that tax would become payable if the supply were taxable.

ACT:
  • Paragraphs 1(o) and 7(c) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 211 of the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  6. Are 90% or more of the parking spaces in the specified parking area reserved for use by persons other than individuals accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No
  7. Is the supply (or the amount of the consideration for the supply) conditional on the parking space being used by a person other than an individual accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No
  8. Was the agreement for the supply entered into in advance and, under its terms, is use of a parking space in the specified parking area made available for a total period of more than 24 hours and the use is to be by a person other than an individual accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No
  9. Was a section 211 election made by the charity in effect for the property where the parking space is situated? – No

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
  • Paragraph 1(o) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 7 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Paragraph 1(o) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 7 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
  4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Paragraph 1(o) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 7 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of real property recently used primarily in commercial activities of the charity

RESULT:

GST/HST taxable where, immediately before the time tax would first become payable in respect of the sale if the sale were taxable, the property is used (otherwise than in making the sale) primarily in commercial activities of the charity

ACT:
Paragraph 1(l) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of real property (that is not a residential complex) to an individual or a personal trust

On the real property being supplied, is a structure situated that was used by the charity as an office or in the course of commercial activities or of making exempt supplies?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of real property (that is not a residential complex) to an individual or a personal trust
  4. On the real property being supplied, is a structure situated that was used by the charity as an office or in the course of commercial activities or of making exempt supplies? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
Paragraph 1(k) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
  3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of real property (that is not a residential complex) to an individual or a personal trust
  4. On the real property being supplied, is a structure situated that was used by the charity as an office or in the course of commercial activities or of making exempt supplies? – No

RESULT:

GST/HST taxable

ACT:
Paragraph 1(k) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Exported supply

RESULT:

Zero-rated
 
ACT:
  • Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Zero-rated exported supplies are excluded from GST/HST exemption under paragraph 1(a) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the ETA
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
See GST/HST Policy Statement P-132, 100% Rebate for Exports by a Charity or a Public Institution

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Services sold for their direct cost

Did the charity buy the service with the intention to sell it?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Services sold for their direct cost
  3. Did the charity buy the service with the intention to sell it? – Yes

Is the total charge for the service the usual charge by the charity for such services to such recipients?

Recipient in this case means the person who an agreement says must pay for the service. If there is no agreement, the recipient would be the person who must pay for the service.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Services sold for their direct cost
  3. Did the charity buy the service with the intention to sell it? – Yes
  4. Is the total charge for the service the usual charge by the charity for such services to such recipients? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt where the charity sells the service at its direct cost. 

If the charity does not charge any amount as GST/HST for the service, its direct cost would mean the charge isn't (and couldn't reasonably be) more than the charity's cost for the service.

If the charity charges any amount as GST/HST for the service, its direct cost would mean the charge for the service isn't (and couldn't reasonably be) the same as, or more than, the charity's cost for the service. The charity's cost would be calculated without including any amount for GST/HST paid.

ACT:
Section 5.1 of Part V.I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Services sold for their direct cost
  3. Did the charity buy the service with the intention to sell it? – Yes
  4. Is the total charge for the service the usual charge by the charity for such services to such recipients? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% unless other legislation exempts or zero-rates the sale for a different reason.

Section 5.1 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Services sold for their direct cost
  3. Did the charity buy the service with the intention to sell it? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% unless other legislation exempts or zero-rates the sale for a different reason.

Section 5.1 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Supply deemed to be made by the charity

What was the Excise Tax Act authority for the supply to be deemed to be made by the charity?

  • Section 187
  • Section 136.1
  • Any other section under Part IX of the Excise Tax Act
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Supply deemed to be made by the charity
  3. What was the Excise Tax Act authority for the supply to be deemed to be made by the charity? – Section 187

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Supply deemed to be made by the charity
  3. What was the Excise Tax Act authority for the supply to be deemed to be made by the charity? – Section 136.1

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt if deemed only under section 136.1

  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Supply deemed to be made by the charity

ACT:
Paragraph 1(b) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Purely cosmetic service to an individual

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% where a service, rendered to an individual, of enhancing/altering the individual's physical appearance is not for medical or reconstructive purposes
 
ACT:
Paragraph 1(p) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
The supply of a right entitling a person to the service is also taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – 90% or more of their supplies made for no consideration

RESULT:

Supplies are GST/HST exempt, other than supplies of:
  • parking spaces by lease, licence or similar arrangement in the course of a business carried on by a charity (see the "Real property" subtopic for charities for rules relating to the tax status of parking spaces)
  • blood or blood derivatives (as those supplies are zero-rated under Schedule VI) 
ACT:
  • Paragraph 1(o) and sections 5 and 7 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Schedule VI to the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Personal property that was used in a commercial activity

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% if the personal property is used (other than in making the supply) in a commercial activity or, in the case of capital property, used "primarily" in a commercial activity. 
The time period of that commercial activity refers to the time immediately before tax would become payable if it were a taxable supply.

ACT:
Paragraph 1(c) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
Personal property means property that is not real property.
 
Capital property of a taxpayer, for GST/HST purposes, means
  • any depreciable property of the taxpayer, and
  • any property (other than depreciable property), any gain or loss from the disposition of which would, if the property were disposed of, be a capital gain or a capital loss, as the case may be, of the taxpayer;
other than property described in Class 12, 14, 14.1 or 44 of Schedule II to the Income Tax Regulations. It also includes, in respect of a person, property that would meet that definition if the person were a taxpayer under the Income Tax Act.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Section 178.7, specified service supplied to a registrant

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

A specified service, as defined in subsection 178.7(1) of the Excise Tax Act (ETA), is removed from the general exempting provision for charities if the supply is made to a registrant at a time when a designation of the charity under section 178.7 is in effect.

ACT:
  1. Paragraph 1(d.1) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the ETA
  2. Subsection 178.7(1) of the ETA
EXPLANATION
Section 1 of Part V.1 of Schedule V exempts most services supplied by charities. Section 178.7 allows eligible charities to apply to be designated so that those supplies become GST/HST taxable to GST/HST-registered customers. The charity could then claim input tax credits for their related inputs.

For the purposes of section 178.7, "specified service" means any service where its recipient is a public sector body or a board, commission or other body established by a government or a municipality, other than a service that is:
  • the care, employment or training for employment of individuals with disabilities,
  • an employment placement service rendered to such individuals, or
  • the provision of instruction to assist such individuals in securing employment.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Tangible personal property (goods) sold for their direct cost

Are the goods capital property?

The direct cost of goods refers to the total consideration that the hospital paid for the goods themselves and any article or material bought to use in the process of their manufacturing, producing, processing or packaging.

Capital property of a taxpayer, for GST/HST purposes, means

  • any depreciable property of the taxpayer, and
  • any property (other than depreciable property), any gain or loss from the disposition of which would, if the property were disposed of, be a capital gain or a capital loss, as the case may be, of the taxpayer;
other than property described in Class 12, 14, 14.1 or 44 of Schedule II to the Income Tax Regulations. It also includes, in respect of a person, property that would meet that definition if the person were a taxpayer under the Income Tax Act.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Tangible personal property (goods) sold for their direct cost
  3. Are the goods capital property? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% unless other legislation exempts or zero-rates the sale for a different reason.

ACT:
Section 5.1 of Part V.I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Tangible personal property (goods) sold for their direct cost
  3. Are the goods capital property? – No

Is the total amount charged by the charity their usual charge for such goods to such recipients?

Recipient in this case means the person who an agreement says must pay for the service. If there is no agreement, the recipient would be the person who must pay for the service.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Tangible personal property (goods) sold for their direct cost
  3. Are the goods capital property? – No
  4. Is the total amount charged by the charity their usual charge for such goods to such recipients? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

If the charity has not charged any amount as GST/HST for its sale of the goods, its direct cost would mean the charge isn't (and couldn't reasonably be) more than the charity's cost for the goods.

If the charity has charged any amount as GST/HST for its sale of the goods, their direct cost would mean the charge for the goods isn't (and couldn't reasonably be) the same as, or more than, the charity's cost for the goods. The charity's cost would be calculated without including any amount for GST/HST paid.

ACT:
Section 5.1 of Part V.I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Tangible personal property (goods) sold for their direct cost
  3. Are the goods capital property? – No
  4. Is the total amount charged by the charity their usual charge for such goods to such recipients? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% unless other legislation exempts or zero-rates the sale for a different reason.

ACT:
  • Section 5.1 of Part V.I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Subsection 123(1) of the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Right to play or participate in a game of chance (other than an admission)

Is the supply a prescribed game of chance?

A prescribed game of chance is one that is conducted by one of the following persons:

  • the Atlantic Lottery Corporation
  • the British Columbia Lottery Corporation
  • the Manitoba Liquor and Lotteries Corporation
  • the Ontario Lottery and Gaming Corporation
  • la Société des loteries et courses du Québec
  • the Western Canada Lottery Corporation
  • the Interprovincial Lottery Corporation
  • the Alberta Gaming and Liquor Commission
  • the Saskatchewan Liquor and Gaming Authority
  • the Saskatchewan Gaming Corporation
  • the New Brunswick Lotteries and Gaming Corporation
  • the Nova Scotia Provincial Lotteries and Casino Corporation

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Right to play or participate in a game of chance (other than an admission)
  3. Is the supply a prescribed game of chance? – Yes

RESULT:
Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Paragraph 1(i) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
  • Sections 3 and 4 of the Games of Chance (GST/HST) Regulations

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Right to play or participate in a game of chance (other than an admission)
  3. Is the supply a prescribed game of chance? – No

RESULT:
GST/HST exempt

ACT:
  • Paragraph 1(i) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
  • Sections 3 and 4 of the Games of Chance (GST/HST) Regulations

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Sale of personal property or a service in the course of a fundraising activity

Does the charity make such supplies on a regular or continuous basis?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Sale of personal property or a service in the course of a fundraising activity
  3. Does the charity make such supplies on a regular or continuous basis? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST taxable if such supplies are made on a regular or continuous basis throughout the year or a significant portion of the year
