Section 3 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity

  3. Does the charity make such supplies on a regular or continuous basis? – No

Does the agreement for the supply entitle the recipient to receive from the charity property or services on a regular or continuous basis?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Sale of personal property or a service in the course of a fundraising activity
  3. Does the charity make such supplies on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  4. Does the agreement for the supply entitle the recipient to receive from the charity property or services on a regular or continuous basis? – Yes

GST/HST taxable if the recipient is entitled to receive the property or services on a regular or continuous basis throughout the year or a significant portion of the year

Is the supply an admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance?

  • No

  3. Does the charity make such supplies on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  4. Does the agreement for the supply entitle the recipient to receive from the charity property or services on a regular or continuous basis? – No

ACT:
Paragraph 3(c) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Sale of personal property or a service in the course of a fundraising activity
  3. Does the charity make such supplies on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  4. Does the agreement for the supply entitle the recipient to receive from the charity property or services on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  5. Is the supply an admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – No

Would the supply be zero-rated under Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Sale of personal property or a service in the course of a fundraising activity
  3. Does the charity make such supplies on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  4. Does the agreement for the supply entitle the recipient to receive from the charity property or services on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  5. Is the supply an admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – No
  6. Would the supply be zero-rated under Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act? – Yes

RESULT:

Zero-rated
 
ACT:
  • Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Paragraph 1(a) and 3(b) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the ETA excludes from GST/HST exemption any supplies that qualify for zero-rating under Schedule VI

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Sale of personal property or a service in the course of a fundraising activity
  3. Does the charity make such supplies on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  4. Does the agreement for the supply entitle the recipient to receive from the charity property or services on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  5. Is the supply an admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – No
  6. Would the supply be zero-rated under Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act? – No

Is the supply deemed to be made by the charity?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Sale of personal property or a service in the course of a fundraising activity
  3. Does the charity make such supplies on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  4. Does the agreement for the supply entitle the recipient to receive from the charity property or services on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  5. Is the supply an admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – No
  6. Would the supply be zero-rated under Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act? – No
  7. Is the supply deemed to be made by the charity? – Yes

RESULT:

See the topic "Supply deemed to be made by the charity" for specific rules explaining which deemed supplies are GST/HST exempt when supplied by a charity.

ACT:
Paragraphs 1(b) and 3(b) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Sale of personal property or a service in the course of a fundraising activity
  3. Does the charity make such supplies on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  4. Does the agreement for the supply entitle the recipient to receive from the charity property or services on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  5. Is the supply an admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – No
  6. Would the supply be zero-rated under Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act? – No
  7. Is the supply deemed to be made by the charity? – No

Is the supply personal property that was used in a commercial activity?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Sale of personal property or a service in the course of a fundraising activity
  3. Does the charity make such supplies on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  4. Does the agreement for the supply entitle the recipient to receive from the charity property or services on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  5. Is the supply an admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – No
  6. Would the supply be zero-rated under Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act? – No
  7. Is the supply deemed to be made by the charity? – No
  8. Is the supply personal property that was used in a commercial activity? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% if the personal property is used (other than in making the supply) in a commercial activity or, in the case of capital property, used "primarily" in a commercial activity. 
The time period of that commercial activity refers to the time immediately before tax would become payable if it were a taxable supply.

ACT:
Paragraphs 1(c) and 3(b) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
Personal property means property that is not real property.
 
Capital property of a taxpayer, for GST/HST purposes, means
  • any depreciable property of the taxpayer, and
  • any property (other than depreciable property), any gain or loss from the disposition of which would, if the property were disposed of, be a capital gain or a capital loss, as the case may be, of the taxpayer;
other than property described in Class 12, 14, 14.1 or 44 of Schedule II to the Income Tax Regulations. It also includes, in respect of a person, property that would meet that definition if the person were a taxpayer under the Income Tax Act.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Sale of personal property or a service in the course of a fundraising activity
  3. Does the charity make such supplies on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  4. Does the agreement for the supply entitle the recipient to receive from the charity property or services on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  5. Is the supply an admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – No

  7. Is the supply deemed to be made by the charity? – No
  8. Is the supply personal property that was used in a commercial activity? – No

Is the supply a right, other than an admission, to play or participate in a game of chance?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Sale of personal property or a service in the course of a fundraising activity
  3. Does the charity make such supplies on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  4. Does the agreement for the supply entitle the recipient to receive from the charity property or services on a regular or continuous basis? – No
  5. Is the supply an admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – No
  6. Would the supply be zero-rated under Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act? – No
  7. Is the supply deemed to be made by the charity? – No
  8. Is the supply personal property that was used in a commercial activity? – No
  9. Is the supply a right, other than an admission, to play or participate in a game of chance? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% where a right, other than an admission, is supplied to play or participate in a game of chance where the charity is a prescribed person or the game is a prescribed game of chance

ACT:
Section 3 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Other supplies that would be zero-rated (taxable at 0%) if supplied by most businesses

RESULT:

Zero-rated
 
ACT:
  • Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Paragraph 1(a) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the ETA excludes from the general exemption any supplies that qualify for zero-rating under Schedule VI
EXAMPLE:
Supplies of medical and assistive devices that are zero-rated under Part II of Schedule VI do not become GST/HST exempt when supplied by a charity.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Lease of personal property in conjunction with an exempt lease of real property by the charity

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt where the personal property is supplied by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement in conjunction with an exempt supply by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement by the charity of real property

ACT:
Paragraphs 1(c) and 1(d) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
Personal property means property that is not real property

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Supplies of performing artists to a person who makes taxable supplies admissions for the performance

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 1(h) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Food, beverages or short-term accommodation supplied to relieve poverty, suffering or distress of individuals

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt if the supply is not for the purpose of fund-raising

ACT:
Section 5.2 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Membership (or other right) entitling person to supervision or instruction in recreational or athletic activity

Who is the membership intended to be provided primarily to?

A supply made by a charity is usually GST/HST exempt but ETA legislation (paragraph 1(f) of Part V.1 of Schedule V) removes from that exemption a service involving, or a membership or other right entitling a person to, supervision or instruction in any recreational or athletic activity except where:

  • it could reasonably be expected, given the nature of the activity or the degree of relevant skill or ability required for participation in it, that such services, memberships or rights supplied by the charity would be provided primarily to children 14 years of age or under and the services are not supplied as part of, the membership is not in, or the right is not in respect of, a program involving overnight supervision throughout a substantial portion of the program, or
  • such services, memberships or rights supplied by the charity are intended to be provided primarily to individuals who are underprivileged or who have a disability
Even of that exemption doesn't apply, however, there are still situations that may exempt it under paragraph 1(g) of Part V.1 of Schedule V.

  • Children 14 years of age or under
  • Individuals who are underprivileged or who have a disability
  • None of the above
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Membership (or other right) entitling person to supervision or instruction in recreational or athletic activity
  3. Who is the membership intended to be provided primarily to? – Children 14 years of age or under

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt where it could reasonably be expected, given the nature of the activity or the degree of relevant skill or ability required for participation in it, that such services, memberships or rights supplied by the charity would be provided primarily to children 14 years of age or under and the services are not supplied as part of, the membership is not in, or the right is not in respect of, a program involving overnight supervision throughout a substantial portion of the program
 
ACT:
Subparagraph 1(f)(i) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Membership (or other right) entitling person to supervision or instruction in recreational or athletic activity
  3. Who is the membership intended to be provided primarily to? – Individuals who are underprivileged or who have a disability

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt
 
ACT:
Subparagraph 1(f)(ii) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Membership (or other right) entitling person to supervision or instruction in recreational or athletic activity
  3. Who is the membership intended to be provided primarily to? – None of the above

Does the membership either entitle the member to an admission (or discount on an admission) for a place of amusement that would be taxable, or include a right, at a place of amusement, to either use facilities or participate in a recreational or athletic activity?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Membership (or other right) entitling person to supervision or instruction in recreational or athletic activity
  3. Who is the membership intended to be provided primarily to? – None of the above
  4. Does the membership either entitle the member to an admission (or discount on an admission) for a place of amusement that would be taxable, or include a right, at a place of amusement, to either use facilities or participate in a recreational or athletic activity? – Yes

Is the value of the admission, discount or right insignificant in relation to the consideration for the membership?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Membership (or other right) entitling person to supervision or instruction in recreational or athletic activity
  3. Who is the membership intended to be provided primarily to? – None of the above
  4. Does the membership either entitle the member to an admission (or discount on an admission) for a place of amusement that would be taxable, or include a right, at a place of amusement, to either use facilities or participate in a recreational or athletic activity? – Yes
  5. Is the value of the admission, discount or right insignificant in relation to the consideration for the membership? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 1(g) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Membership (or other right) entitling person to supervision or instruction in recreational or athletic activity
  3. Who is the membership intended to be provided primarily to? – None of the above
  4. Does the membership either entitle the member to an admission (or discount on an admission) for a place of amusement that would be taxable, or include a right, at a place of amusement, to either use facilities or participate in a recreational or athletic activity? – Yes
  5. Is the value of the admission, discount or right insignificant in relation to the consideration for the membership? – No

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
Paragraph 1(g) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Membership (or other right) entitling person to supervision or instruction in recreational or athletic activity
  3. Who is the membership intended to be provided primarily to? – None of the above
  4. Does the membership either entitle the member to an admission (or discount on an admission) for a place of amusement that would be taxable, or include a right, at a place of amusement, to either use facilities or participate in a recreational or athletic activity? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 1(g) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Food or beverages supplied under a program to seniors, underprivileged individuals or individuals with a disability

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt when under a program established and operated for the purpose of providing prepared food to such individuals in their places of residence. Supplies of food or beverages made to the charity for the purpose of the program are also GST/HST exempt.

ACT:
Section 4 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the charity for the purpose of making a sale of the property

Was the property donated to the charity or used by another person before it was acquired by the charity?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the charity for the purpose of making a sale of the property
  3. Was the property donated to the charity or used by another person before it was acquired by the charity? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
Paragraph 1(d) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the charity for the purpose of making a sale of the property
  3. Was the property donated to the charity or used by another person before it was acquired by the charity? – No

Was the property supplied by the charity under a contract for catering?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the charity for the purpose of making a sale of the property
  3. Was the property donated to the charity or used by another person before it was acquired by the charity? – No
  4. Was the property supplied by the charity under a contract for catering? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
Paragraph 1(d) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the charity for the purpose of making a sale of the property
  3. Was the property donated to the charity or used by another person before it was acquired by the charity? – No
  4. Was the property supplied by the charity under a contract for catering? – No

Was the property supplied for its direct cost?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the charity for the purpose of making a sale of the property
  3. Was the property donated to the charity or used by another person before it was acquired by the charity? – No
  4. Was the property supplied by the charity under a contract for catering? – No
  5. Was the property supplied for its direct cost? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt if the total charge for the supply is the usual charge by the charity for such supplies to such recipients and:
  • if the charity does not charge the recipient any amount as GST/HST for the supply, the total charge for the supply does not, and could not reasonably be expected to, exceed the direct cost of the supply; and
  • if the charity charges the recipient an amount as GST/HST the supply, the consideration for the supply does not, and could not reasonably be expected to, equal or exceed the direct cost of the supply determined without reference to either:
  • GST/HST imposed under Part IX of the Excise Tax Act, or
  • QST that became payable under the first paragraph of section 16 of An Act respecting the Québec sales tax, R.S.Q., c. T-0.1, at a time when the charity was a registrant as defined in section 1 of that Act.

ACT:
Section 5.1 of Part V.I of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the charity for the purpose of making a sale of the property
  3. Was the property donated to the charity or used by another person before it was acquired by the charity? – No
  4. Was the property supplied by the charity under a contract for catering? – No
  5. Was the property supplied for its direct cost? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 1(d) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
Any service supplied by the charity is also taxable if it is in respect of such a taxable supply of property.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Supply of designated municipal property, if the charity is a person designated to be a municipality for the purposes of section 259 of the Excise Tax Act

RESULT:

Removed from the general GST/HST exemption that is specific to charities. See the topic under the category of Municipalities for further information.

ACT:
Paragraph 1(n) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
  2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – None of the above

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt
 
ACT:
Section 1 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)

Which best describes the supply?

  • Supply made by a provincial or territorial government
  • Supply made to a provincial or territorial government
  • Supply made from one provincial or territorial government to another
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made by a provincial or territorial government

Which best describes the supply made by the government?

As a supplier, a provincial or territorial government is required to register for the GST/HST, as well as to collect and remit tax for taxable supplies it makes, and file GST/HST returns.

Provincial and territorial governments, including their Crown agents, provide various types of property and services in the course of fulfilling their mandates and responsibilities. As with most businesses, some of these supplies are GST/HST taxable and some are exempt.

There are also certain supplies that are exempt specifically when made by a provincial or territorial government.

  • Garbage and recycling collection
  • Certain property registration system services
  • A right to deposit refuse at a refuse disposal site
  • Supplies that are exempt when supplied by most businesses
  • Certain services involving registration system for a court
  • Certain supplies relating to a right to have access to documents
  • Certain supplies relating to a licence, permit, quota or similar right
  • At least 90% of the property, like a brochure, supplied by a government, are provided for free
  • At least 90% of the service, such as training, supplied by a government, are provided for free
  • A law enforcement service or a fire protection service made to a government or to a board, commission or other body established by a government
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made by a provincial or territorial government
  3. Which best describes the supply made by the government? – Garbage and recycling collection

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
Paragraph 20(h) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 18.2, Provincial Governments

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made by a provincial or territorial government
  3. Which best describes the supply made by the government? – Certain property registration system services

RESULT:

The following are GST/HST exempt:
  • registering, or processing an application to register, any property in a property registration system
  • filing, or processing an application to file, any document in a property registration system
  • a right to have access to, or to use, a property registration system to register, or make application to register, any property in it or to file, or make application to file, any document in it
However, the exemption does not apply to a supply of a right to enter, to have access to or to use property of the government, other than a right, referred to above, to have access to, or to use, a filing or registration system.


ACT:
Paragraph 20(a) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

EXAMPLE:
The registration of a mortgage in a property registration system by a provincial or territorial government would be exempt.

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 18.2, Provincial Governments

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made by a provincial or territorial government
  3. Which best describes the supply made by the government? – A right to deposit refuse at a refuse disposal site

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
Paragraph 20(i) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 18.2, Provincial Governments

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made by a provincial or territorial government
  3. Which best describes the supply made by the government? – Supplies that are exempt when supplied by most businesses

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
See the "Most businesses" area of this interactive tool for details on tax status of supplies whem made by most businesses.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made by a provincial or territorial government
  3. Which best describes the supply made by the government? – Certain services involving registration system for a court

RESULT:

The following are GST/HST exempt:
  • filing, or processing an application to file, a document in the registration system of a court or in accordance with legislative requirements
  • a right to have access to, or to use, the registration system of a court, or any other registration system in which documents are filed in accordance with legislative requirements, for the purpose of filing a document in that registration system
  • issuing or providing, or processing an application to issue or provide, a document from the registration system of a court or other similar tribunal
  • a right to have access to, or to use, the registration system of a court or other similar tribunal to issue or obtain a document from that registration system
However, the exemption does not apply to a supply of a right to enter, to have access to or to use property of the government, other than a right, referred to above, to have access to, or to use, a filing or registration system.

ACT:
Paragraph 20(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 18.2, Provincial Governments

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made by a provincial or territorial government
  3. Which best describes the supply made by the government? – Certain supplies relating to a right to have access to documents

RESULT:

The following are GST/HST exempt:
  • a service of providing information under the Privacy Act, the Access to Information Act or any similar provincial legislation
  • the vital statistics, residency, citizenship or right to vote of any person
  • the registration of any person for any service provided by a government or municipality or by a board, commission or other body established by a government or municipality
  • any other status of any person
  • the title to, or any right or estate in, property
  • any encumbrance or assessment in respect of property
  • the zoning of real property

ACT:
Paragraphs 20(d), 20(e) and 20(f) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 18.2, Provincial Governments

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made by a provincial or territorial government
  3. Which best describes the supply made by the government? – Certain supplies relating to a licence, permit, quota or similar right

Is the right or service in respect of the importation of alcoholic beverages?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made by a provincial or territorial government
  3. Which best describes the supply made by the government? – Certain supplies relating to a licence, permit, quota or similar right
  4. Is the right or service in respect of the importation of alcoholic beverages? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 20(c) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made by a provincial or territorial government
  3. Which best describes the supply made by the government? – Certain supplies relating to a licence, permit, quota or similar right
  4. Is the right or service in respect of the importation of alcoholic beverages? – No

RESULT:

The following are GST/HST exempt:
  • a licence, permit, quota or similar right
  • a service of processing an application for a licence, permit, quota or similar right
  • a right to have access to, or to use, a filing or registration system to make application for a licence, permit, quota or similar right
However, the exemption does not apply to:
  • a supply to a consumer of a right to hunt or fish,
  • a supply of a right to take or remove forestry products, products that grow in water, fishery products, minerals or peat, where the supply is made to either a consumer, or a person who is not a registrant and who acquires the right in the course of a business of the person of making supplies of the products, minerals or peat to consumers
  • a supply of a right to enter, to have access to or to use property of the government, municipality or other body other than a right, referred to in this tool's topics, to have access to, or to use, a filing or registration system

ACT:
Paragraph 20(c) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 18.2, Provincial Governments

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made by a provincial or territorial government
  3. Which best describes the supply made by the government? – At least 90% of the property, like a brochure, supplied by a government, are provided for free

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt, unless the supply is of either:
  • blood or blood derivatives
  • a parking space if the supply is made for consideration by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement in the course of a business carried on by the provincial or territorial government

ACT:
Section 10 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 18.2, Provincial Governments

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made by a provincial or territorial government
  3. Which best describes the supply made by the government? – At least 90% of the service, such as training, supplied by a government, are provided for free

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
Section 10 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 18.2, Provincial Governments

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made by a provincial or territorial government
  3. Which best describes the supply made by the government? – A law enforcement service or a fire protection service made to a government or to a board, commission or other body established by a government

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
Paragraph 20(g) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 18.2, Provincial Governments

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made to a provincial or territorial government

RESULT:

GST/HST is payable by most provincial or territorial governments on their purchases of taxable property and services.

However, listed entities in Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta, the Northwest Territories and Yukon do not pay the GST/HST on purchases of taxable property and services, provided that an authorized official of the listed entity provides sufficient evidence to the supplier that the supplies are being purchased by a listed entity on its own behalf.

ACT:
Section 122 of the Excise Tax Act (ETA)

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
Provincial and territorial governments and their Crown agents are not bound as purchasers by the provisions of the ETA.

However, all provinces and territories other than New Brunswick and Alberta have entered into RTAs in which they have, among other things, negotiated how the particular province or territory (and its listed entities) will receive relief from the GST/HST on their purchases of taxable property and services.
 
As a result, there are ways in which a provincial or territorial government and its listed entities may be eligible for relief from the GST/HST on its purchases.

Depending on the government entity, those ways may be through claiming either a government rebate of 100% of the GST/HST or point-of-purchase relief from payment of the GST/HST.

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 18.2, Provincial Governments

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made from one provincial or territorial government to another

Are the supplies being made between entities within the same provincial or territorial government GST/HST registration?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made from one provincial or territorial government to another
  3. Are the supplies being made between entities within the same provincial or territorial government GST/HST registration? – Yes

RESULT:

No GST/HST applies

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
Transactions between entities that are branches or divisions of the same provincial or territorial government registration are not treated as supplies for purposes of the GST/HST. Therefore, GST/HST does not apply to supplies of property or services between those entities.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Government (provincial and territorial)
  2. Which best describes the supply? – Supply made from one provincial or territorial government to another
  3. Are the supplies being made between entities within the same provincial or territorial government GST/HST registration? – No

RESULT:

The GST/HST rules that apply are generally the same as would apply to supplies by most businesses when the Crown corporations, and certain boards, commissions and agencies are involved predominantly in commercial activities and are required to register separately for the GST/HST.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital

Who is making the supply?

Public institution means a registered charity (within the meaning subsection 248(1) of the Income Tax Act) that is also a:

  • school authority
  • public college
  • university
  • hospital authority
  • local authority determined to be a municipality under paragraph (b) of the definition of municipality in subsection 123(1) of the Excise Tax Act
For educational services from other types of suppliers, see "Educational services" under the topic "Most businesses"

  • Updated - University
  • Updated - Public college
  • Updated - School authority
  • Finished - Vocational school
  • In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  • In progress (David P) - Municipality
  • Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - University

Which best describes the supply being made by the university?

University means a recognized degree-granting institution or an organization that operates a college affiliated with, or a research body of, such an institution.

See "Public institution" instead if the university is also a registered charity within the meaning assigned by subsection 248(1) of the Income Tax Act.

  • Finished - Mandatory fees
  • Finished - Course materials
  • Finished - Vocational courses
  • Finished - Second language instruction in English or French
  • Finished - Courses in respect of professional or trade accreditations or designations
  • Finished - Instructing individuals in, or administering exams for, courses for which credit toward a diploma or degree may be obtained
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - University
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the university? – Finished - Mandatory fees

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt if:
  • the fees are for a supply of a service or membership, and
  • the consideration for those fees is required to be paid by the recipient of a supply included in section 7 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA) because the recipient receives the supply included in section 7 (for example, for instruction in courses offered by a university for which credit may be obtained toward a diploma)
EXAMPLE:
Supplies of various student club memberships are GST/HST exempt where the consideration for these supplies must be paid by students because they receive a supply that is exempt under section 7 of Part III of Schedule V to the ETA.

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
There is no requirement that the supplies under section 7.1 and section 7 be made by the same supplier. The exemption under section 7.1 applies even if the supply is made to students who are not enrolled in a diploma program.
 
Also, although the exemption does not apply to mandatory fees in respect of a supply of goods (such as a musical instrument or lab equipment) that are required for use in a course, those supplies may be exempt under another section of the ETA.

ACT:
Section 7.1 of Part III of Schedule V to the ETA

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.3, Universities

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - University
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the university? – Finished - Course materials

Are the course materials part of a single supply with a GST/HST exempt service of instruction?

Students often purchase course materials that relate to a service of instruction, such as textbooks, dictionaries, notes and compact discs, from the person supplying the service of instruction. The course materials may either be part of a single supply of a service of instruction that consists of several elements or be supplied separately from the supply of a service of instruction.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - University
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the university? – Finished - Course materials
  4. Are the course materials part of a single supply with a GST/HST exempt service of instruction? – Yes

RESULT:

The course materials included in the single supply of GST/HST exempt instruction would also be exempt.
 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Policy Statement P-077R2, Single and Multiple Supplies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - University
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the university? – Finished - Course materials
  4. Are the course materials part of a single supply with a GST/HST exempt service of instruction? – No

RESULT:

The separate supply of the course materials would not be GST/HST exempt under Part III of Schedule V and would be taxable unless another exempting provision of the Excise Tax Act applies to the supply.
 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Policy Statement P-077R2, Single and Multiple Supplies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - University
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the university? – Finished - Vocational courses

Is the course being supplied to a non-resident?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - University
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the university? – Finished - Vocational courses
  4. Is the course being supplied to a non-resident? – Yes

Is the recipient of the service a non-registrant that is not an individual but the service is of instructing non-resident individuals?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - University
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the university? – Finished - Vocational courses
  4. Is the course being supplied to a non-resident? – Yes
  5. Is the recipient of the service a non-registrant that is not an individual but the service is of instructing non-resident individuals? – Yes

RESULT:

Zero-rated (regardless of whether a university is providing the service) if the service is of instructing non-resident individuals in courses leading to certificates, diplomas, licences or similar documents, or classes or ratings in respect of licences, that attest to the competence of individuals to practise or perform a trade or vocation. A service of administering an examination in respect of such a situation is also exempt.
 
ACT:
Section 18 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE:
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.3, Universities
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.4, Vocational Schools and Courses

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - University
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the university? – Finished - Vocational courses
  4. Is the course being supplied to a non-resident? – Yes
  5. Is the recipient of the service a non-registrant that is not an individual but the service is of instructing non-resident individuals? – No

RESULT:

These university courses are GST/HST exempt if the service is of instructing individuals in courses leading to certificates, diplomas, licences or similar documents, or classes or ratings in respect of licences, that attest to the competence of individuals to practise or perform a trade or vocation. A service of administering an examination in respect of such a university course is also exempt.
 
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
The exempting legislation also provides the supplier of such courses the option of electing to make the course fees taxable.
 
ACT:
Section 8 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE:
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.3, Universities
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.4, Vocational Schools and Courses

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - University
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the university? – Finished - Vocational courses
  4. Is the course being supplied to a non-resident? – No

RESULT:

These university courses are GST/HST exempt if the service is of instructing individuals in courses leading to certificates, diplomas, licences or similar documents, or classes or ratings in respect of licences, that attest to the competence of individuals to practise or perform a trade or vocation. A service of administering an examination in respect of such a university course is also exempt.
 
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
The exempting legislation also provides the supplier of such courses the option of electing to make the course fees taxable.
 
ACT:
Section 8 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE:
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.3, Universities
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.4, Vocational Schools and Courses

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - University
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the university? – Finished - Second language instruction in English or French

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt (instructing individuals in, or administering examinations in respect of, language courses that form part of a program of second‑language instruction in either English or French)

ACT:
Section 11 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.3, Universities

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - University
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the university? – Finished - Courses in respect of professional or trade accreditations or designations

RESULT:

These university courses are GST/HST exempt if the service is of instructing individuals in courses leading to, or for the purpose of maintaining or upgrading, a professional or trade accreditation or designation recognized by a regulatory body. The supply of a certificate, or a service of administering an examination, in respect of such a university course is also exempt.
 
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
The exempting legislation also provides the supplier of such courses the option of electing to make the course fees taxable.
 
ACT:
Section 6 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.3, Universities

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - University
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the university? – Finished - Instructing individuals in, or administering exams for, courses for which credit toward a diploma or degree may be obtained

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt tuition and examination fees if they are paid to a university for a service of instructing individuals in, or administering examinations in respect of, courses for which credit toward a diploma or degree may be obtained.
 
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
The supply made by a university of a service of instructing in credit courses is exempt even if the supply is made to students who are not enrolled in a diploma or degree program. Therefore, the exemption applies to supplies of instruction in courses for which credit toward a diploma or degree may be obtained where those courses are offered by a university, either at night as part of a continuing education program or during the day, even if some students are not taking the courses as part of a diploma or degree program.
 
ACT:
Section 7 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.3, Universities

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - Public college

Which best describes the supply being made by the public college?

See "Public institution" instead if the public college is also a registered charity within the meaning assigned by subsection 248(1) of the Income Tax Act.

Public college means an organization that operates a post-secondary college or post-secondary technical institute where both of the following conditions have been met:

  • it receives from a government or a municipality funds that are paid for the purpose of assisting the organization in the ongoing provision of educational services to the general public
  • its primary purpose is to provide programs of instruction in one or more fields of vocational, technical or general education

  • Finished - Mandatory fees
  • Finished - Course materials
  • Finished - Vocational courses
  • Finished - Courses that are part of a program
  • Finished - Second language instruction in English or French
  • Finished - Courses in respect of professional or trade accreditations or designations
  • Finished - Instructing individuals in, or administering exams for, courses for which credit toward a diploma or degree may be obtained
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - Public college
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the public college? – Finished - Mandatory fees

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt if:
  • the fees are for a supply of a service or membership, and
  • the consideration for those fees is required to be paid by the recipient of a supply included in section 7 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA) because the recipient receives the supply included in section 7 (for example, for instruction in courses offered by a public college for which credit may be obtained toward a diploma)
EXAMPLE:
Supplies of various student club memberships are GST/HST exempt where the consideration for these supplies must be paid by students because they receive a supply that is exempt under section 7 of Part III of Schedule V to the ETA.

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
There is no requirement that the supplies under section 7.1 and section 7 be made by the same supplier. The exemption under section 7.1 applies even if the supply is made to students who are not enrolled in a diploma program.
 
Also, although the exemption does not apply to mandatory fees in respect of a supply of goods (such as a musical instrument or lab equipment) that are required for use in a course, those supplies may be exempt under another section of the ETA.

ACT:
Section 7.1 of Part III of Schedule V to the ETA

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.2, Public Colleges

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - Public college
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the public college? – Finished - Course materials

Are the course materials part of a single supply with a GST/HST exempt service of instruction?

Students often purchase course materials that relate to a service of instruction, such as textbooks, dictionaries, notes and compact discs, from the person supplying the service of instruction. The course materials may either be part of a single supply of a service of instruction that consists of several elements or be supplied separately from the supply of a service of instruction.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - Public college
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the public college? – Finished - Course materials
  4. Are the course materials part of a single supply with a GST/HST exempt service of instruction? – Yes

RESULT:

The course materials included in the single supply of GST/HST exempt instruction would also be exempt.
 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Policy Statement P-077R2, Single and Multiple Supplies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - Public college
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the public college? – Finished - Course materials
  4. Are the course materials part of a single supply with a GST/HST exempt service of instruction? – No

RESULT:

The separate supply of the course materials would not be GST/HST exempt under Part III of Schedule V and would be taxable unless another exempting provision of the Excise Tax Act applies to the supply.
 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Policy Statement P-077R2, Single and Multiple Supplies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - Public college
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the public college? – Finished - Vocational courses

Is the course being supplied to a non-resident?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - Public college
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the public college? – Finished - Vocational courses
  4. Is the course being supplied to a non-resident? – Yes

Is the recipient of the service a non-registrant that is not an individual but the service is of instructing non-resident individuals?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - Public college
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the public college? – Finished - Vocational courses
  4. Is the course being supplied to a non-resident? – Yes
  5. Is the recipient of the service a non-registrant that is not an individual but the service is of instructing non-resident individuals? – Yes

RESULT:

Zero-rated if the service is of instructing non-resident individuals in courses leading to certificates, diplomas, licences or similar documents, or classes or ratings in respect of licences, that attest to the competence of individuals to practise or perform a trade or vocation. A service of administering an examination in respect of such a situation is also exempt.
 
ACT:
Section 18 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE:
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.2, Public Colleges
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.4, Vocational Schools and Courses

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - Public college
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the public college? – Finished - Vocational courses
  4. Is the course being supplied to a non-resident? – Yes
  5. Is the recipient of the service a non-registrant that is not an individual but the service is of instructing non-resident individuals? – No

RESULT:

These courses are GST/HST exempt if the service is of instructing individuals in courses leading to certificates, diplomas, licences or similar documents, or classes or ratings in respect of licences, that attest to the competence of individuals to practise or perform a trade or vocation. A service of administering an examination in respect of such a course is also exempt.
 
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
The exempting legislation also provides the supplier of such courses the option of electing to make the course fees taxable.
 
ACT:
Section 8 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE:
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.2, Public Colleges
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.4, Vocational Schools and Courses

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - Public college
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the public college? – Finished - Vocational courses
  4. Is the course being supplied to a non-resident? – No

RESULT:

These courses are GST/HST exempt if the service is of instructing individuals in courses leading to certificates, diplomas, licences or similar documents, or classes or ratings in respect of licences, that attest to the competence of individuals to practise or perform a trade or vocation. A service of administering an examination in respect of such a course is also exempt.
 
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
The exempting legislation also provides the supplier of such courses the option of electing to make the course fees taxable.
 
ACT:
Section 8 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE:
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.2, Public Colleges
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.4, Vocational Schools and Courses

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - Public college
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the public college? – Finished - Courses that are part of a program

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt if the supply made by a public college is of a service of instructing individuals in, or administering examinations in respect of, courses that are part of a program that consists of 2 or more courses and that is subject to review of, and is approved by, a council, board or committee of the public college established to review and approve the course offerings of that public college.

Specifically excluded from this exemption are courses in sports, games, hobbies or other recreational pursuits that are designed to be taken primarily for recreational purposes.

ACT:
Section 16 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.2, Public Colleges

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - Public college
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the public college? – Finished - Second language instruction in English or French

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt (instructing individuals in, or administering examinations in respect of, language courses that form part of a program of second‑language instruction in either English or French)

ACT:
Section 11 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.7, Second Language Instruction

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - Public college
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the public college? – Finished - Courses in respect of professional or trade accreditations or designations

RESULT:

These courses are GST/HST exempt if the service is of instructing individuals in courses leading to, or for the purpose of maintaining or upgrading, a professional or trade accreditation or designation recognized by a regulatory body. The supply of a certificate, or a service of administering an examination, in respect of such a course is also exempt.
 
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
The exempting legislation also provides the supplier of such courses the option of electing to make the course fees taxable.
 
ACT:
Section 6 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.2, Public Colleges

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - Public college
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the public college? – Finished - Instructing individuals in, or administering exams for, courses for which credit toward a diploma or degree may be obtained

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt tuition and examination fees if they are paid to a public college for a service of instructing individuals in, or administering examinations in respect of, courses for which credit toward a diploma or degree may be obtained.
 
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
The supply made by a public college of a service of instructing in credit courses is exempt even if the supply is made to students who are not enrolled in a diploma or degree program. Therefore, the exemption applies to supplies of instruction in courses for which credit toward a diploma or degree may be obtained where those courses are offered by a public college, either at night as part of a continuing education program or during the day, even if some students are not taking the courses as part of a diploma or degree program.
 
ACT:
Section 7 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.2, Public Colleges

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - School authority

Which best describes the supply being made by the school authority?

See "Public institution" instead if the school authority is also a registered charity within the meaning assigned by subsection 248(1) of the Income Tax Act.

School authority means an organization that operates an elementary or secondary school in which it provides instruction that meets the standards of educational instruction established by the government of the province or territory in which the school is operated.

  • School bus
  • Mandatory fees
  • Food and beverages
  • Student transportation
  • Elementary or secondary school instruction
  • Second language instruction in English or French
  • Instructing individuals in, or administering exams for, courses for which credit toward a diploma or degree may be obtained
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - School authority
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the school authority? – School bus

RESULT:

A supply made by a school authority to a person (other than to another school authority) of a service of transporting elementary or secondary school students to or from a school that is operated by a school authority is GST/HST exempt.

ACT:
Section 5 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 28.3, Passenger Transportation Services

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - School authority
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the school authority? – Mandatory fees

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt if:
  • the fees are for a supply of a service or membership, and
  • the consideration for those fees is required to be paid by the recipient of a supply included in section 7 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA) because the recipient receives the supply included in section 7 (for example, for instruction in courses offered by a school authority for which credit may be obtained toward a diploma)
EXAMPLE:
Supplies of various student club memberships are GST/HST exempt where the consideration for these supplies must be paid by students because they receive a supply that is exempt under section 7 of Part III of Schedule V to the ETA.

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
There is no requirement that the supplies under section 7.1 and section 7 be made by the same supplier. The exemption under section 7.1 applies even if the supply is made to students who are not enrolled in a diploma program.

Also, although the exemption does not apply to mandatory fees in respect of a supply of goods (such as a musical instrument or lab equipment) that are required for use in a course, those supplies may be exempt under another section of the ETA.

ACT:
Section 7.1 of Part III of Schedule V to the ETA

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.1, School Authorities - Elementary and Secondary Schools

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - School authority
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the school authority? – Food and beverages

How is the school authority supplying the food and beverages?

  • Vending machine
  • School cafeteria
  • During extra-curricular activities
  • Prescribed foods (for example, carbonated beverages, prepackaged snack foods, candy)
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - School authority
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the school authority? – Food and beverages
  4. How is the school authority supplying the food and beverages? – Vending machine

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Section 12 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCES:
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.1, School Authorities - Elementary and Secondary Schools
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.5, School Cafeterias, University and Public College Meal Plans, and Food Service Providers

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - School authority
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the school authority? – Food and beverages
  4. How is the school authority supplying the food and beverages? – School cafeteria

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt. However, the GST/HST exemption does not apply to food or beverages that are:
  • supplied through a vending machine
  • prescribed by the Regulations (for example, prepackaged snack foods and carbonated beverages)
ACT:
  • Section 12 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
  • School Cafeteria Food and Beverage (GST/HST) Regulations

REFERENCES:
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.1, School Authorities - Elementary and Secondary Schools
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.5, School Cafeterias, University and Public College Meal Plans, and Food Service Providers

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - School authority
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the school authority? – Food and beverages
  4. How is the school authority supplying the food and beverages? – During extra-curricular activities

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt as long as supplied primarily to elementary or secondary school students during the course of extra‑curricular activities organized under the authority and responsibility of the school authority.

However, the GST/HST exemption does not apply to food or beverages that are:
  • supplied through a vending machine
  • prescribed by the Regulations (for example, prepackaged snack foods and carbonated beverages)
ACT:
  • Section 3 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 12 of Part III of Schedule V to the ETA
  • School Cafeteria Food and Beverage (GST/HST) Regulations

REFERENCES:
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.1, School Authorities - Elementary and Secondary Schools
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.5, School Cafeterias, University and Public College Meal Plans, and Food Service Providers

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - School authority
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the school authority? – Food and beverages
  4. How is the school authority supplying the food and beverages? – Prescribed foods (for example, carbonated beverages, prepackaged snack foods, candy)

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%. The general GST/HST exemption for food and beverages supplied by a school authority does not apply to the following food and beverages, which are prescribed by the Regulations:
  • carbonated beverages
  • non-carbonated fruit juice beverages that contain less than 25% by volume of natural fruit juice, when sold in cans, cartons, or bottles
  • candies and confectionery that are prepackaged for sale to consumers
  • snack foods that are prepackaged for sale to consumers

ACT:
  • School Cafeteria Food and Beverage (GST/HST) Regulations
  • Section 3 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 12 of Part III of Schedule V to the ETA

REFERENCES:
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.1, School Authorities - Elementary and Secondary Schools
  • GST/HST Memorandum 20.5, School Cafeterias, University and Public College Meal Plans, and Food Service Providers

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - School authority
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the school authority? – Student transportation

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt (a supply of a service of transporting elementary or secondary school students to or from a school operated by a school authority when the supply is made by a school authority to a person other than another school authority)

ACT:
Section 5 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.1, School Authorities - Elementary and Secondary Schools

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - School authority
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the school authority? – Elementary or secondary school instruction

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt ("a supply made by a school authority in a province of a service of instructing individuals in a course that is provided primarily [more than 50%] for elementary or secondary school students”)

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
As long as the “primarily for” condition is met, the supply of instruction to individuals other than elementary or secondary school students may qualify for the GST/HST exemption. Since the wording is “provided primarily for” rather than “provided primarily to”, this condition will be satisfied as long as the course is provided with the intent that primarily elementary or secondary school students will be taking the course.

ACT:
Section 2 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.1, School Authorities - Elementary and Secondary Schools

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - School authority
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the school authority? – Second language instruction in English or French

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt (instructing individuals in, or administering examinations in respect of, language courses that form part of a program of second‑language instruction in either English or French)

ACT:
Section 11 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.1, School Authorities - Elementary and Secondary Schools

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Updated - School authority
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the school authority? – Instructing individuals in, or administering exams for, courses for which credit toward a diploma or degree may be obtained

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt tuition and examination fees if they are paid to a school authority for a service of instructing individuals in, or administering examinations in respect of, courses for which credit toward a diploma or degree may be obtained.
 
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
The supply of a service of instructing in credit courses made by a school authority is exempt even if the supply is made to students who are not enrolled in a diploma program. Therefore, the exemption applies to supplies of instruction in courses for which credit toward a diploma may be obtained where those courses are offered by a school authority, either at night as part of a continuing education program or during the day, even if some students are not taking the courses as part of a diploma program.

ACT:
Section 7 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.1, School Authorities - Elementary and Secondary Schools

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Finished - Vocational school

Which best describes the supply being made by the vocational school?

Vocational school means an organization that is established and operated primarily to provide students with correspondence courses, or instruction in courses, that develop or enhance students’ occupational skills.

  • Finished - Course materials
  • Finished - Vocational courses
  • Finished - Second language instruction in English or French
  • Finished - Courses in respect of professional or trade accreditations or designations
  • Finished - Course being supplied to a non-registrant non-resident that is not an individual
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Finished - Vocational school
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the vocational school? – Finished - Course materials

Are the course materials part of a single supply with a GST/HST exempt service of instruction?

Students often purchase course materials that relate to a service of instruction, such as textbooks, dictionaries, notes and compact discs, from the person supplying the service of instruction. The course materials may either be part of a single supply of a service of instruction that consists of several elements or be supplied separately from the supply of a service of instruction.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Finished - Vocational school
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the vocational school? – Finished - Course materials
  4. Are the course materials part of a single supply with a GST/HST exempt service of instruction? – Yes

RESULT:

The course materials included in the single supply of GST/HST exempt instruction would also be exempt.
 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Policy Statement P-077R2, Single and Multiple Supplies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Finished - Vocational school
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the vocational school? – Finished - Course materials
  4. Are the course materials part of a single supply with a GST/HST exempt service of instruction? – No

RESULT:

The separate supply of the course materials would not be GST/HST exempt under Part III of Schedule V and would be taxable unless another exempting provision of the Excise Tax Act applies to the supply.
 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Policy Statement P-077R2, Single and Multiple Supplies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Finished - Vocational school
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the vocational school? – Finished - Vocational courses

RESULT:

These courses are GST/HST exempt if the service is of instructing individuals in courses leading to certificates, diplomas, licences or similar documents, or classes or ratings in respect of licences, that attest to the competence of individuals to practise or perform a trade or vocation. A service of administering an examination in respect of such a course is also exempt.
 
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
The exempting legislation also provides the supplier of such courses the option of electing to make the course fees taxable.
 
ACT:
Section 8 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.4, Vocational Schools and Courses

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Finished - Vocational school
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the vocational school? – Finished - Second language instruction in English or French

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt (instructing individuals in, or administering examinations in respect of, language courses that form part of a program of second‑language instruction in either English or French)

ACT:
Section 11 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.7, Second Language Instruction

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Finished - Vocational school
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the vocational school? – Finished - Courses in respect of professional or trade accreditations or designations

RESULT:
