These courses are GST/HST exempt if the service is of instructing individuals in courses leading to, or for the purpose of maintaining or upgrading, a professional or trade accreditation or designation recognized by a regulatory body. The supply of a certificate, or a service of administering an examination, in respect of such a course is also exempt.
 
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
The exempting legislation also provides the supplier of such courses the option of electing to make the course fees taxable.
 
ACT:
Section 6 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.4, Vocational Schools and Courses

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – Finished - Vocational school
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the vocational school? – Finished - Course being supplied to a non-registrant non-resident that is not an individual

RESULT:

Zero-rated if the service is of instructing non-resident individuals in courses leading to certificates, diplomas, licences or similar documents, or classes or ratings in respect of licences, that attest to the competence of individuals to practise or perform a trade or vocation. A service of administering an examination in respect of such a situation is also exempt.
 
ACT:
Section 18 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
 
REFERENCE:
GST/HST Memorandum 20.4, Vocational Schools and Courses

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital

Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital?

See "Public institution" instead if the supplier is a hospital authority as well as a registered charity within the meaning assigned by subsection 248(1) of the Income Tax Act.

  • Finished - Healthcare services
  • Finished - Services sold for their direct cost
  • In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  • Finished - Medical devices or prescription drugs
  • Finished - Sale of tangible personal property (goods)
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Healthcare services

See "Most businesses" to find out if these supplies are taxable, zero-rated or exempt.

EXAMPLE:

To find out whether certain services by a medical doctor are taxable or exempt, see "Healthcare services" under the "Most businesses" topic. 

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Services sold for their direct cost

Did the hospital buy the service with the intention to sell it?

These scenarios show whether the sale is taxable when made by a public hospital that is designated by the Minister of National Revenue as a hospital authority.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Services sold for their direct cost
  4. Did the hospital buy the service with the intention to sell it? – Yes

Is the total charge for the service the usual charge by the hospital for such services to such recipients?

Recipient in this case means the person who an agreement says must pay for the service. If there is no agreement, the recipient would be the person who must pay for the service.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Services sold for their direct cost
  4. Did the hospital buy the service with the intention to sell it? – Yes
  5. Is the total charge for the service the usual charge by the hospital for such services to such recipients? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt where the hospital sells the service at its direct cost. 

If the hospital does not charge any amount as GST/HST for the service, its direct cost would mean the charge isn't (and couldn't reasonably be) more than the hospital's cost for the service.

If the hospital charges any amount as GST/HST for the service, its direct cost would mean the charge for the service isn't (and couldn't reasonably be) the same as, or more than, the hospital's cost for the service. The hospital's cost would be calculated without including any amount for GST/HST paid.

ACT:
Section 6 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Services sold for their direct cost
  4. Did the hospital buy the service with the intention to sell it? – Yes
  5. Is the total charge for the service the usual charge by the hospital for such services to such recipients? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%, unless other legislation exempts or zero-rates the sale for a different reason

ACT:
Section 6 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Services sold for their direct cost
  4. Did the hospital buy the service with the intention to sell it? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% unless other legislation exempts or zero-rates the sale for a different reason.

ACT:
Section 6 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)

Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property?

These scenarios show whether the supply of real property is taxable, zero-rated or exempt when made by a public hospital that is designated by the Minister of National Revenue as a hospital authority.

  • Finished - Lease of a parking space
  • Finished - Supply was deemed to be made for GST/HST purposes
  • Finished - Lease or licence (other than short term accommodation)
  • Finished - Sale of real property to an individual or a personal trust
  • Finished - Lease of real property used primarily in the hospital's commercial activities
  • Finished - Before being supplied by the hospital, the real property was last supplied to the hospital by being deemed under subsection 183(1)
  • Finished - Sale or lease of real property when a Form GST26 election is in effect (to have an exempt supply of real property treated as a taxable supply)
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space

Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
  5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes

For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital?

Specified parking area for a parking space means all of the parking spaces that could be chosen for use in parking under the agreement for the supply of the parking space if all of those parking spaces were vacant and none were reserved for specific users.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
  5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  6. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes

Which of the following apply?

The GST/HST exemption for use of a parking space is generally intended for individuals going to a public hospital as a patient or a visitor, but the overall intended use of the specified parking area impacts the exemption.

  • A Form GST26 election is in effect (to have an exempt supply of real property treated as a taxable supply)
  • 90% or more of the parking spaces are reserved for use by persons who are not individuals accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity
  • The price for (or the ability to use) the parking space is conditional on it being used by persons who are individual accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity
  • Advance agreement for parking space to be available for a total of more than 24 hours and for its use by persons who are not individuals accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity
  • None of the above
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
  5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  6. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  7. Which of the following apply? – A Form GST26 election is in effect (to have an exempt supply of real property treated as a taxable supply)

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Paragraph 25.1(c) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 211 of the ETA

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
  • Form GST26, Election or Revocation of an Election by a Public Service Body to Have an Exempt Supply of Real Property Treated as a Taxable Supply
  • GST/HST Notice 285, Application of the GST/HST to Supplies of Parking by Charities and Public Sector Bodies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
  5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  6. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  7. Which of the following apply? – 90% or more of the parking spaces are reserved for use by persons who are not individuals accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25.1(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
GST/HST Notice 285, Application of the GST/HST to Supplies of Parking by Charities and Public Sector Bodies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
  5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  6. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  7. Which of the following apply? – The price for (or the ability to use) the parking space is conditional on it being used by persons who are individual accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25.1(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
GST/HST Notice 285, Application of the GST/HST to Supplies of Parking by Charities and Public Sector Bodies

EXAMPLE:
A hospital in Calgary, Alberta charges their employees a reduced rate to park in their lot. Hospital visitors are charged the full price to park in the same lot. The hospital would charge GST on the parking spaces.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
  5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  6. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  7. Which of the following apply? – Advance agreement for parking space to be available for a total of more than 24 hours and for its use by persons who are not individuals accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25.1(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

EXAMPLE:
A hospital employee in Edmonton, Alberta enters into an agreement to pay for the next month's parking pass. The sale of the pass would be taxable at the GST rate of 5%.

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
GST/HST Notice 285, Application of the GST/HST to Supplies of Parking by Charities and Public Sector Bodies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
  5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  6. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
  7. Which of the following apply? – None of the above

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
Section 25.1 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
  5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
  6. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25.1(a) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

EXAMPLE:
A parking lot in Windsor, Ontario is shared and available for someone to access a public hospital or various nearby businesses. There are no designated areas identifying which of the parking spaces are for the hospital and which are for the other businesses. 13% HST would be charged on the parking space.
 
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
GST/HST Notice 285, Application of the GST/HST to Supplies of Parking by Charities and Public Sector Bodies

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
  5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25(h) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Supply was deemed to be made for GST/HST purposes

Was the supply only deemed to have been made because of lease interval rules found in section 136.1?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Supply was deemed to be made for GST/HST purposes
  5. Was the supply only deemed to have been made because of lease interval rules found in section 136.1? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

ACT:
  • Paragraph 25(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 136.1 of the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Supply was deemed to be made for GST/HST purposes
  5. Was the supply only deemed to have been made because of lease interval rules found in section 136.1? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease or licence (other than short term accommodation)

Which best describes the supply of real property?

Short-term accommodation means a period of occupancy or a right of occupancy by an individual in a residential complex or a residential unit that is supplied by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement for a period of less than one month where such occupation is for use as a place of residence or lodging. The period of occupancy is calculated as a period where the same individual is given continuous occupancy, notwithstanding that the rental may be on a daily or weekly basis.

  • Licence
  • Lease for continuous possession of one month or more
  • Lease for continuous possession of less than one month
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease or licence (other than short term accommodation)
  5. Which best describes the supply of real property? – Licence

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Paragraph 25(f) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Subsection 123(1) of the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease or licence (other than short term accommodation)
  5. Which best describes the supply of real property? – Lease for continuous possession of one month or more

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt unless the specific type of supply is removed for a different reason from the general exemption for supplies of real property by a public sector body that is a hospital 

ACT:
Paragraph 25(f) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease or licence (other than short term accommodation)
  5. Which best describes the supply of real property? – Lease for continuous possession of less than one month

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% if the supply is made in the course of a business carried on by the hospital

ACT:
  • Paragraph 25(f) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Subsection 123(1) of the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Sale of real property to an individual or a personal trust

Is there a structure on the property that was used as an office or in the course of either commercial activities or of making exempt supplies?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Sale of real property to an individual or a personal trust
  5. Is there a structure on the property that was used as an office or in the course of either commercial activities or of making exempt supplies? – Yes

Was the property used primarily in the hospital's commercial activities immediately before tax would be payable if it were a taxable sale?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Sale of real property to an individual or a personal trust
  5. Is there a structure on the property that was used as an office or in the course of either commercial activities or of making exempt supplies? – Yes
  6. Was the property used primarily in the hospital's commercial activities immediately before tax would be payable if it were a taxable sale? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraphs 25(c) and 25(d) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Sale of real property to an individual or a personal trust
  5. Is there a structure on the property that was used as an office or in the course of either commercial activities or of making exempt supplies? – Yes
  6. Was the property used primarily in the hospital's commercial activities immediately before tax would be payable if it were a taxable sale? – No

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt unless the specific type of supply is removed for a different reason from the general exemption for supplies of real property by a public sector body that is a hospital

ACT:
Paragraphs 25(c) and 25(d) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Sale of real property to an individual or a personal trust
  5. Is there a structure on the property that was used as an office or in the course of either commercial activities or of making exempt supplies? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25(c) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of real property used primarily in the hospital's commercial activities

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 13% if it was used more than 50% in the hospital's commercial activites immediately before tax would be payable if it were a taxable supply

ACT:
Paragraph 25(d) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

EXAMPLE:
A hospital leased space to a tenant operating a flower shop. The lease expired and new tenants signed a lease. Because the hospital's lease to the flower shop was a commercial (GST/HST-taxable) activity, lease of the space is also taxable for the new tenant.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Before being supplied by the hospital, the real property was last supplied to the hospital by being deemed under subsection 183(1)

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
Paragraph 25(i) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – In progress - Real property (includes parking)
  4. Which best describes the hospital's supply of real property? – Finished - Sale or lease of real property when a Form GST26 election is in effect (to have an exempt supply of real property treated as a taxable supply)

RESULT:

GST/HST taxable if the election is in effect at the time GST/HST would become payable in respect of the supply if it were a taxable supply
 
ACT:
  • Paragraph 25(g) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Section 211 of the ETA

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
  • Form GST26, Election or Revocation of an Election by a Public Service Body to Have an Exempt Supply of Real Property Treated as a Taxable Supply

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Medical devices or prescription drugs

See "Most businesses" to find out if these supplies are taxable, zero-rated or exempt.

EXAMPLE:

To find out whether the sale of a cane or a crutch is taxable or exempt, see "Medical devices or prescription drugs" under the "Most businesses" topic. 

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Sale of tangible personal property (goods)

Is the hospital selling the goods at their direct cost?

The direct cost of goods refers to the total consideration that the hospital paid for the goods themselves and any article or material bought to use in the process of their manufacturing, producing, processing or packaging.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Sale of tangible personal property (goods)
  4. Is the hospital selling the goods at their direct cost? – Yes

Are the goods capital property?

Capital property of a taxpayer, for GST/HST purposes, means

  • any depreciable property of the taxpayer, and
  • any property (other than depreciable property), any gain or loss from the disposition of which would, if the property were disposed of, be a capital gain or a capital loss, as the case may be, of the taxpayer;
other than property described in Class 12, 14, 14.1 or 44 of Schedule II to the Income Tax Regulations. It also includes, in respect of a person, property that would meet that definition if the person were a taxpayer under the Income Tax Act.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Sale of tangible personal property (goods)
  4. Is the hospital selling the goods at their direct cost? – Yes
  5. Are the goods capital property? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% unless other legislation exempts or zero-rates the sale for a different reason.

ACT:
Section 6 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Sale of tangible personal property (goods)
  4. Is the hospital selling the goods at their direct cost? – Yes
  5. Are the goods capital property? – No

Is the total amount charged by the hospital their usual charge for such goods to such recipients?

Recipient in this case means the person who an agreement says must pay for the goods. If there is no agreement, the recipient would be the person who must pay for the goods.

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Sale of tangible personal property (goods)
  4. Is the hospital selling the goods at their direct cost? – Yes
  5. Are the goods capital property? – No
  6. Is the total amount charged by the hospital their usual charge for such goods to such recipients? – Yes

RESULT:

GST/HST exempt

If the hospital has not charged any amount as GST/HST for its sale of the goods, its direct cost would mean the charge isn't (and couldn't reasonably be) more than the hospital's cost for the goods.

If the hospital has charged any amount as GST/HST for its sale of the goods, their direct cost would mean the charge for the goods isn't (and couldn't reasonably be) the same as, or more than, the hospital's cost for the goods. The hospital's cost would be calculated without including any amount for GST/HST paid.

ACT:
Section 6 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

EXAMPLE:
If a hospital collected GST/HST on a sale of their inventory, but the pre-tax price charged by the hospital was less than their direct cost of purchasing the items (excluding GST/HST plus QST), the hospital's sale would have actually been exempt. The GST/HST the hospital collected on the sale would have been collected in error and should be refunded.

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Sale of tangible personal property (goods)
  4. Is the hospital selling the goods at their direct cost? – Yes
  5. Are the goods capital property? – No
  6. Is the total amount charged by the hospital their usual charge for such goods to such recipients? – No

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% unless other legislation exempts or zero-rates the sale for a different reason.

ACT:
  • Section 6 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Subsection 123(1) of the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Sale of tangible personal property (goods)
  4. Is the hospital selling the goods at their direct cost? – No

Is the hospital selling excisable goods?

These scenarios show whether the sale of tangible personal property is taxable, zero-rated or exempt when made by a public hospital that is designated by the Minister of National Revenue as a hospital authority.

Excisable goods means:

  • beer or malt liquor (within the meaning assigned by section 4 of the Excise Act), and
  • spirits, wine, tobacco products, cannabis products and vaping products (within the meaning assigned by section 2 of the Excise Act, 2001)

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Sale of tangible personal property (goods)
  4. Is the hospital selling the goods at their direct cost? – No
  5. Is the hospital selling excisable goods? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

ACT:
  • Section 4 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
  • Subsection 123(1) of the ETA

  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Sale of tangible personal property (goods)
  4. Is the hospital selling the goods at their direct cost? – No
  5. Is the hospital selling excisable goods? – No

Does the hospital carry on the business of selling such goods?

  • Yes
  • No
  1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
  2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (Angele) - Hospital
  3. Which best describes the supply being made by the hospital? – Finished - Sale of tangible personal property (goods)
  4. Is the hospital selling the goods at their direct cost? – No
  5. Is the hospital selling excisable goods? – No
  6. Does the hospital carry on the business of selling such goods? – Yes

RESULT:

Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% unless there is a different reason that tax legislation either makes the sale exempt or zero-rated (taxable at 0%).

Paragraph 4(a) of Part VI of Schedule V to the ETA

    EXAMPLE:

    To find out whether the sale of a cane or a crutch is taxable or exempt, see "Medical devices or prescription drugs" under the "Most businesses" topic. 

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
    2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (David P) - Municipality
    3. In progress - Which best describes the supply being made by the municipality? – References for building mapping

    Guide RC4049, GST/HST Information for Municipalities

    GST/HST Technical Information Bulletin B-046, Administrative Guidelines for Municipalities

    Schedule V of the Excise Tax Act lists a number of current exemptions for the supply of certain property and services by one municipality to another.

    In addition to the exemptions currently provided, the Department of Finance has advised that GST/HST will not apply to a supply between:

    • a municipality and one of its para-municipals
    • para-municipals of the same municipality
    • a regional government or one of its para-municipals, and a municipality operating within the jurisdiction of that regional government or one of that municipality's para-municipals
    The following will still be taxable unless one of the exemptions in Schedule V applies:
    • supplies between neighbouring municipalities even if they are within the same regional government;
    • supplies between para-municipals of neighbouring municipalities, even if they are within the same regional government;
    • supplies between the para-municipal of one municipality and a neighbouring municipality.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
    2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (David P) - Municipality
    3. In progress - Which best describes the supply being made by the municipality? – In progress - Licences and permits

    Decision

      1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
      2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (David P) - Municipality
      3. In progress - Which best describes the supply being made by the municipality? – Finished - Municipal transit services

      Are the supplies being made to a transit authority?

      Municipal transit services are public passenger transportation services, or a right that exclusively entitles an individual to use such services that are supplied by a transit authority.

      Municipal transit services do not include charter services or services that are part of a tour.

      • Yes
      • No

      2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (David P) - Municipality
      3. In progress - Which best describes the supply being made by the municipality? – Finished - Municipal transit services
      4. Are the supplies being made to a transit authority? – Yes

      RESULT:

      Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

        1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
        2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (David P) - Municipality
        3. In progress - Which best describes the supply being made by the municipality? – In progress - Personal property and capital personal property

        Add question here

        Personal property means property that is not real property.
         
        Capital property of a taxpayer, for GST/HST purposes, means

        • any depreciable property of the taxpayer, and
        • any property (other than depreciable property), any gain or loss from the disposition of which would, if the property were disposed of, be a capital gain or a capital loss, as the case may be, of the taxpayer;
        other than property described in Class 12, 14, 14.1 or 44 of Schedule II to the Income Tax Regulations. It also includes, in respect of a person, property that would meet that definition if the person were a taxpayer under the Income Tax Act.

        • a
        • b

        2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (David P) - Municipality
        3. In progress - Which best describes the supply being made by the municipality? – In progress - Personal property and capital personal property

          2. Who is making the supply? – In progress (David P) - Municipality
          3. In progress - Which best describes the supply being made by the municipality? – In progress - Personal property and capital personal property
          4. Add question here – b

            • Para-municipals of the same municipality
            • Supplies between neighbouring municipalities

            • Supplies between para-municipals of neighbouring municipalities

            • A regional government or one of its para-municipals, and a municipality operating within the jurisdiction of that regional government or one of that municipality's para-municipals

            ACT:

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution

            Which best describes the supply?

            Most supplies made by public institutions are GST/HST exempt while most supplies made by businesses are taxable.

            • Catering
            • Exported supply
            • Real property (including parking)
            • Supply deemed to be made by the public institution
            • Personal property that was used in a commercial activity
            • Other supplies that would be zero-rated (taxable at 0%) if supplied by most businesses
            • Supplies of performing artists to a person who makes taxable supplies admissions for the performance
            • In progress - Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property by the institution
            • Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the institution for the purpose of making a sale of the property
            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Catering

            RESULT:

            Supply is taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% when the property or service is made by the institution under a contract for catering for an event or occasion sponsored or arranged by another person who contracts with the institution for catering

            ACT:
            • Paragraph 2(e) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
            • Paragraph 2(g) of Part VI of Schedule V to the ETA

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Exported supply

            RESULT:

            Zero-rated
             
            ACT:
            • Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
            • Zero-rated exported supplies are excluded from GST/HST exemption under paragraph 2(a) of Part VI of Schedule V to the ETA
            ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
            See GST/HST Policy Statement P-132, 100% Rebate for Exports by a Charity or a Public Institution

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Real property (including parking)

            Which best describes the public institution's supply of real property?

            • Finished - Lease of a parking space
            • Finished - Sale of a residential complex
            • Finished - Sale of real property to an individual or a personal trust
            • Finished - Sale or lease of real property used more than 50% in the public institution's commercial activities
            • Finished - Sale or lease of real property when a Form GST26 election is in effect (to have an exempt supply of real property treated as a taxable supply)
            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Real property (including parking)
            4. Which best describes the public institution's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space

            Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital?

            • Yes
            • No
            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Real property (including parking)
            4. Which best describes the public institution's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
            5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes

            For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital?

            Specified parking area for a parking space means all of the parking spaces that could be chosen for use in parking under the agreement for the supply of the parking space if all of those parking spaces were vacant and none were reserved for specific users.

            • Yes
            • No
            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Real property (including parking)
            4. Which best describes the public institution's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
            5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
            6. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes

            Which of the following apply?

            The GST/HST exemption for use of a parking space is generally intended for individuals going to a public hospital as a patient or a visitor, but the overall intended use of the specified parking area impacts the exemption.

            • A Form GST26 election is in effect (to have an exempt supply of real property treated as a taxable supply)
            • 90% or more of the parking spaces are reserved for use by persons who are not individuals accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity
            • The price for (or the ability to use) the parking space is conditional on it being used by persons who are individual accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity
            • Advance agreement for parking space to be available for a total of more than 24 hours and for its use by a persons who are not individuals accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity
            • None of the above
            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Real property (including parking)
            4. Which best describes the public institution's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
            5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
            6. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
            7. Which of the following apply? – A Form GST26 election is in effect (to have an exempt supply of real property treated as a taxable supply)

            RESULT:

            Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

            ACT:
            • Paragraph 25.1(c) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
            • Section 211 of the ETA

            ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
            • Form GST26, Election or Revocation of an Election by a Public Service Body to Have an Exempt Supply of Real Property Treated as a Taxable Supply
            • GST/HST Notice 285, Application of the GST/HST to Supplies of Parking by Charities and Public Sector Bodies

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Real property (including parking)
            4. Which best describes the public institution's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
            5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
            6. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
            7. Which of the following apply? – 90% or more of the parking spaces are reserved for use by persons who are not individuals accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity

            RESULT:

            Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

            ACT:
            Paragraph 25.1(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

            ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
            GST/HST Notice 285, Application of the GST/HST to Supplies of Parking by Charities and Public Sector Bodies

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Real property (including parking)
            4. Which best describes the public institution's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
            5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
            6. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
            7. Which of the following apply? – The price for (or the ability to use) the parking space is conditional on it being used by persons who are individual accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity

            RESULT:

            Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

            ACT:
            Paragraph 25.1(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

            ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
            GST/HST Notice 285, Application of the GST/HST to Supplies of Parking by Charities and Public Sector Bodies

            EXAMPLE:
            A hospital in Calgary, Alberta charges their employees a reduced rate to park in their lot. Hospital visitors are charged the full price to park in the same lot. The hospital would charge GST on the parking spaces.

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Real property (including parking)
            4. Which best describes the public institution's supply of real property? – Finished - Lease of a parking space
            5. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
            6. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
            7. Which of the following apply? – Advance agreement for parking space to be available for a total of more than 24 hours and for its use by a persons who are not individuals accessing the hospital in a non-professional capacity

            RESULT:

            Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

            ACT:
            Paragraph 25.1(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

            EXAMPLE:
            A hospital employee in Edmonton, Alberta enters into an agreement to pay for the next month's parking pass. The sale of the pass would be taxable at the GST rate of 5%.

            ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
            GST/HST Notice 285, Application of the GST/HST to Supplies of Parking by Charities and Public Sector Bodies

            7. Which of the following apply? – None of the above

            RESULT:

            GST/HST exempt

            ACT:
            Section 25.1 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Real property (including parking)

            6. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – No

            RESULT:

            Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

            ACT:
            Paragraph 25.1(a) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

            EXAMPLE:
            A parking lot in Windsor, Ontario is shared and available for someone to access a public hospital or various nearby businesses. There are no designated areas identifying which of the parking spaces are for the hospital and which are for the other businesses. 13% HST would be charged on the parking space.

            RESULT:

            Although removed from the general GST/HST exemption for real property found in section 25 of Part VI of Schedule V, the sale may be GST/HST exempt for other reasons. For more information for this type of supply, see the "Real property" subtopic under the category "Most businesses".

            Paragraphs 25(c) and 25(d) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution

            ACT:
            Paragraph 25(c) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Real property (including parking)
            4. Which best describes the public institution's supply of real property? – Finished - Sale or lease of real property used more than 50% in the public institution's commercial activities

            RESULT:

            Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% if it was used more than 50% in their commercial activities immediately before tax would be payable if it were a taxable supply

            ACT:
            Paragraph 25(d) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Real property (including parking)
            4. Which best describes the public institution's supply of real property? – Finished - Sale or lease of real property when a Form GST26 election is in effect (to have an exempt supply of real property treated as a taxable supply)

            RESULT:

            GST/HST taxable if the election is in effect at the time GST/HST would become payable in respect of the supply if it were a taxable supply

            Paragraph 2(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution

            ACT:
            Paragraph 2(b) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Personal property that was used in a commercial activity

            Is the property being supplied capital property?

            Personal property means property that is not real property.

            Capital property of a taxpayer, for GST/HST purposes, means

            • any depreciable property of the taxpayer, and
            • any property (other than depreciable property), any gain or loss from the disposition of which would, if the property were disposed of, be a capital gain or a capital loss, as the case may be, of the taxpayer;
            other than property described in Class 12, 14, 14.1 or 44 of Schedule II to the Income Tax Regulations. It also includes, in respect of a person, property that would meet that definition if the person were a taxpayer under the Income Tax Act.

            • Yes
            • No
            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Personal property that was used in a commercial activity
            4. Is the property being supplied capital property? – Yes

            Was the property used primarily (more than 50%) in commercial activities of the institution?

            The time period of that commercial activity refers to the time immediately before tax would become payable if it were a taxable supply.

            • Yes
            • No
            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Personal property that was used in a commercial activity
            4. Is the property being supplied capital property? – Yes
            5. Was the property used primarily (more than 50%) in commercial activities of the institution? – Yes

            RESULT:

            Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

            ACT:
            Paragraph 2(d) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Personal property that was used in a commercial activity
            4. Is the property being supplied capital property? – Yes
            5. Was the property used primarily (more than 50%) in commercial activities of the institution? – No

            ACT:
            Paragraph 2(d) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Personal property that was used in a commercial activity
            4. Is the property being supplied capital property? – No

            RESULT:

            Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% if the property is not property that was acquired, manufactured or produced by the institution for the purpose of making a supply of the property. 

            The time period of that commercial activity refers to the time immediately before tax would become payable if it were a taxable supply.
             
            ACT:
            Paragraph 2(c) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Other supplies that would be zero-rated (taxable at 0%) if supplied by most businesses

            RESULT:

            Zero-rated
             
            ACT:
            • Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
            • Paragraph 2(a) of Part VI of Schedule V to the ETA excludes from the general exemption any supplies that qualify for zero-rating under Schedule VI
            EXAMPLE:
            Supplies of medical and assistive devices that are zero-rated under Part II of Schedule VI do not become GST/HST exempt when supplied by a public institution.

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – Supplies of performing artists to a person who makes taxable supplies admissions for the performance

            RESULT:

            Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

            ACT:
            Paragraph 2(i) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

            1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
            2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
            3. Which best describes the supply? – In progress - Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property by the institution

            Decision

              1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
              2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
              3. Which best describes the supply? – Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the institution for the purpose of making a sale of the property

              Was the property donated to the institution or used by another person before it was acquired by the institution?

              • Yes
              • No
              1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
              2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
              3. Which best describes the supply? – Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the institution for the purpose of making a sale of the property
              4. Was the property donated to the institution or used by another person before it was acquired by the institution? – Yes

              RESULT:

              GST/HST exempt

              ACT:
              Paragraph 2(e) of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

              1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
              2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
              3. Which best describes the supply? – Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the institution for the purpose of making a sale of the property
              4. Was the property donated to the institution or used by another person before it was acquired by the institution? – No

              Was the property supplied by the institution under a contract for catering?

              • Yes
              • No
              1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
              2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
              3. Which best describes the supply? – Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the institution for the purpose of making a sale of the property
              4. Was the property donated to the institution or used by another person before it was acquired by the institution? – No
              5. Was the property supplied by the institution under a contract for catering? – Yes

              RESULT:

              Supply is taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% when the property or service is made by the institution under a contract for catering for an event or occasion sponsored or arranged by another person who contracts with the institution for catering

              ACT:
              • Paragraph 1(e) of Part IV of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
              • Paragraph 1(g) of Part IV of Schedule V to the ETA

              1. Which best describes the business activity? – In progress - Municipality, university, school or hospital
              2. Who is making the supply? – Finished once paragraph 2(f) of Part VI of Sch V wording updated for Lease of personal property in conjunction with a taxable, short-term lease of real property - Public institution
              3. Which best describes the supply? – Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the institution for the purpose of making a sale of the property
              4. Was the property donated to the institution or used by another person before it was acquired by the institution? – No
              5. Was the property supplied by the institution under a contract for catering? – No

              RESULT:

              Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% unless the specific type of supply is GST/HST exempt for a different reason

              ACT:
              Paragraph 1(e) of Part IV of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

              1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished once webpage links are added - Indigenous customer or supplier

              Which best describes the situation?

              Generally, every sale, lease or other supply made in Canada is GST/HST taxable at the rate of 5%, 13%, or 15%, based on subsections 165(1) and 165(2) of the Excise Tax Act, unless it is specifically listed as being:

              • zero-rated (taxable at 0%) under Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
              • GST/HST exempt under Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

              • Supply made on a reserve
              • Supply made off-reserve to a status Indian, Indian band or band council
              1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished once webpage links are added - Indigenous customer or supplier
              2. Which best describes the situation? – Supply made on a reserve

              Direct the user of the tool to the proper webpage due to the nature of the information

              2. Which best describes the situation? – Supply made off-reserve to a status Indian, Indian band or band council
